Mr. Lorenzo Letourneau,
Agent of Indian Affairs,
St. Constant,
Co. Laprairie, P.Q.

Dear Sir:

As understood with you when we were in St. Constant the other day, you will find attached statement of account in triplicate for the light and stove accounts at the teacher's residence in Caughnawaga.

You will notice that, in the month of May 1933, the readings for light and stove were about the same, as the difference was only 2 kilowatt-hours. The reading for light was 4250 and the one for stove was 4252. Our collector has mixed the readings in June; the reading shown for the light account was the reading of the stove meter, and the reading shown for the stove account was the reading of the light meter. The error has happened due to the meters looking exactly the same, and our collector did not follow the circuits to know which was the stove and which was the light.

This error has been running up the month of March, and the reason for finding it was that we checked up the readings and found that there was quite a difference in the consumption with the previous years. This can be verified with your Department in Ottawa.

The difference between what has been paid and what should have been paid is $102.16 net, as we have figured the discount every month on both statements. We would ask you to kindly take the matter up with the Department of Indian Affairs and ask them to let us have a cheque to cover at their earliest convenience.

We hope this will not cause you too much trouble in any way.

Yours very truly,

THE SHAWINIGAN WATER & POWER COMPANY,
Commercial & Distribution Department.

JDB/J.

District Accountant.
Ottawa, April 9, 1934.

Reverend & Dear Sister:

Enclosed are copies of accounts which we have just received from the Shawinigan Water & Power Company, also copy of their letter dated March 23rd to Mr. Agent Letourneau.

It is almost impossible for the Department to check this account in such a manner as to decide whether or not it should be paid. I would appreciate very much if you would give the matter some consideration and let me have your views regarding the Company's request. I may add that, from our experience, it appears that this Company is extremely careless in the manner in which they prepare their accounts, as we are continually having difficulty with them.

When replying, you should return the enclosed accounts.

Yours sincerely,

Rev. Sister Mary Francis,
Supervising Principal,
R. C. Indian Day Schools,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.
My dear Mr. Phelan:

I have looked over very carefully the electricity accounts accompanying your letter of the 9th instant and am quite astonished to find such exorbitant prices charged for the January and March consumption, as our mode of living is always practically the same. Our lights are extinguished at 9 P.M. every night. Nothing extraordinary occurred during these months that would require extra lighting and we fail to see why there is such a sudden rise in rates unless a short circuit has arisen somewhere or the meters fail to register correctly. So many things depend on the electric current -- door-bell, oil burner, water supply, frigidaire, that we are at a loss to find out just what increases the cost so abruptly.

The electric stove is very seldom used except when the water pipe bursts in the coal stove and a new water front has to be put in. At such times the cooking is done, with great inconvenience, on the electric stove for only a day or two. Moreover, all the hot water required in the house has to be heated during this time on the electric stove until the coal stove has been repaired. The electric stove gave us some trouble in December and January as two lids refused to heat. Upon mentioning this fact to the Indian Agent, he sent a workman to replace the switches and lids. We do not know if this trouble had anything to do with the rise in the bill for these months.

All the meters on the Reserve were replaced by new ones, last November.

I know for a certainty that soon after this change the Missionary put in a complaint for the big rise in the
in the electric accounts. Finally, he made new contracts with the Shawinigan Company because too many things had been placed on the light account. Since January, his accounts went down about $5.00 per month. Would this be our case?

Would you advise us to call in an expert electrician to see if the electric wiring is in good condition as well as the meter boxes? At any rate, we have decided to ask the collector, on his next visit, to teach us how to read the meter so that we ourselves can keep a record of the consumption from time to time and send you the same when required.

We are sorry we are unable to give further explanations concerning this matter.

Respectfully yours,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, May 14th, 1934.

(Encl.)

Sir,

I beg to refer to your voucher #3975 with which you forwarded a letter dated 23rd March, from The Shawinigan Water and Power Co., Valleyfield, wherein they claim $102.16 on account of the readings of the meters for the Electric Stove and Electric Lights at the teachers' residence having become mixed.

For your information I attach a statement showing the energy consumption of the meters in question for 1932 and 1933 as taken from the paid accounts on file here.

You will observe that the total K.W.H. for the Stove in 1932 was 1513 whilst during the same months of 1933 we paid for 3344 K.W.H.

According to the letter from the Shawinigan Co., we should only have paid for 1400 K.W.H as the figure of 3344 should have been shown as the readings of the meter for the Lights, not the Stove, and the same remarks apply to the Lights part of our statement.

On the face of our statement it would appear that the claim of the Shawinigan Water and Power Co. is a just one but before making a final decision in the matter the Department would appreciate your comments on the following points,-

a) Is there any difference in appearance between the two meters?

Lorenzo Letourneau, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Constant,
P.Q.
b) Have any steps been taken to mark which meter is for the Stove and which for the Lights?

c) Are you, or is anyone at the Residence capable of reading the meters?

d) The Stove accounts paid from November 1933 to March 1934 show a very decided increase whilst the Light accounts show a corresponding decrease. Did you make any enquiry as to the reason for this?

e) The "corrected" accounts for Light also show a sharp rise, particularly for the last three months. Please ascertain the reason for this.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 14th instant in connection with the claim of $102.16 from The Shawinigan Water and Power Company, Valleyfield, and to reply as follows to your five questions:

a) - The two meters are placed into the basement of the teachers' residence, near one another, there is a slight difference between the two meters. From the appearance of these two iron boxes, and apart from the Company's officers, it was impossible to tell which was for the stove, or the lights.

b) - Yes, since the mistake is discovered, the meter reader has made a special mark to one of them.

c) - I am told by the Rev. Sister Superior that she and the other teachers are not used to such readings. I occasionally read the meters.

d) - I admit that in this particular case I have not made an enquiry as to the reason for this.

e) - I may say that the fuel oil blower and the water system being connected on to the Light meter, together with the very severe weather during these mentioned months, this was the reason for such a rise to the accounts.

I wish to add that the mistake of the meter readings was made when a newly appointed meter reader first noticed an almost equal amount of K.W.H. on both meters, and he kept on the same readings during a few months until he happen to turn on one of the switches that he then found his mistake.

Dear Sir:

As understood with you when we were in St. Constant the other day, you will find attached statement of account in triplicate for the light and stove accounts at the teacher's residence in Caughnawaga.

You will notice that, in the month of May 1933, the readings for light and stove were about the same, as the difference was only 2 kilowatt-hours. The reading for light was 4250 and the one for stove was 4252. Our collector has mixed the readings in June; the reading shown for the light account was the reading of the stove meter, and the reading shown for the stove account was the reading of the light meter. The error has happened due to the meters looking exactly the same, and our collector did not follow the circuits to know which was the stove and which was the light.

This error has been running up the month of March, and the reason for finding it was that we checked up the readings and found that there was quite a difference in the consumption with the previous years. This can be verified with your Department in Ottawa.

The difference between what has been paid and what should have been paid is $102.16 net, as we have figured the discount every month on both statements. We would ask you to kindly take the matter up with the Department of Indian Affairs and ask them to let us have a cheque to cover at their earliest convenience.

We hope this will not cause you too much trouble in any way.

Yours very truly,

THE SHAWINIGAN WATER & POWER COMPANY,

MEMORANDUM

Dr.

On 24th March last the Indian Agent at Caughnawaga forwarded for payment a voucher in favour of the Shawinigan Water & Power Company, amounting to $102.16, representing the sum claimed by this company owing to the readings of the stove and light meters at the teachers' residence at Caughnawaga having been reversed between the months of May, 1933, and March, 1934.

Sir:-

The Sisters in charge of the Catholic Schools at Caughnawaga have recently been presented with an automobile by one of their friends, and their Superior has called at the Indian office in order that the Department be requested to supply them with gasoline to operate the car, which will be solely used to take the teachers from their residence to the schools and back. Sister Superior also requested that the building, which was formerly occupied as the fire pump station, be repaired in order to be used as a heated garage for the winter.

The repairs needed at this building will cost about $35.00; the repairs are consisting in the widening of the door (which is too narrow) the repairing of the roof and the addition of a ceiling. I would kindly ask you to let me know if the Department is willing to pay for the gasoline for use of this car on the Reserve and on Government business and also if you will authorize the necessary repairs to the garage, so as they can use the car all winter.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, in which you advise that the Sisters in charge of the Catholic Schools at Caughnawaga have recently been presented with an automobile and that they request the Department to supply gasoline to operate the car.

This is the first application of its kind that the Department has received and, before deciding whether or not we can comply with the Sisters' request, it is necessary to have some additional information.

Please let me know the approximate number of gallons of gasoline that would be required each month and also its cost. For some years' past, we have been allowing $2 a week for a messenger boy's services and also a certain amount for the transportation of the teachers on rainy days. In the event of the Department authorizing gasoline for the car, is it to be understood that the charges for a messenger boy and driving the Sisters will be discontinued?

Please consult the Reverend Sisters and advise the Department further in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant with regard to the request made by the Sisters of Caughnawaga for the supplying of oil and gas for use of the automobile, which has recently been presented to them by one of their friends. You mentioned in your communication that the Department paid accounts amounting to over $300 for messenger boy and transportation of the teachers during the academic year 1933-1934.

In reply I beg to transmit you the following report and recommendation in the case.

The Sisters would be willing to accept the amount of $300 or $30 a month for the 10 months of the academic year for the allowance of the car. This allowance would cover the salary of the messenger boy, their transportation etc., it is also understood that this amount would also cover the transportation of the freight and parcels coming to Caughnawaga from the Department or elsewhere for the use of the Schools, Hospital, the Doctor etc.

My recommendation in this case would be to give a fixed allowance of $25 a month to the Sisters for the use of their car, for 10 months a year, starting in September of each year and ending in June, which would make a total allowance of $250 per academic year. This sum should cover the expenditure for the messenger boy, the transportation of the teacher and would be final, no other allowance should be allowed with regard to the above mentioned services.

It is presumed that an amount of $25 per month paid to the Sisters would be preferable than the sending of monthly accounts to the Department for gas and oil for the car, and by allowing a definite amount for the car's expenses if the car is used for other trips those pertaining to Government's affairs the Sisters will have to defray the cost of their trips themselves. It would also be preferable to know in advance the amount of money required for the above mentioned services.

The Secretary

Ottawa, Ont.

Sir;

Recently, Rev. Sister Mary Cleophas, Principal of Caughnawaga R.C. Schools, requested me to draw your attention to the inconvenience of their present Residence. The Sister claims that their Residence is too small; that they are 15 persons living there and that some of them have to sleep in parlors, as they have no rooms for them. She also claims that this house is very cold during the winter months; that certain part of the roof will have to be repaired, as it leaks; that the heating system is giving them trouble, and will need considerable repairs. She also reported that the electric wiring is dangerous, and that their Residence is considered as a regular firetrap.

Therefore she is kindly requesting the Department to consider the building of a new Residence for the teachers, which she claims had been decided in the past but postpone owing to uncontrollable circumstances.

Your obedient servant

Indian Agent

The Secretary

Ottawa, April 23, 1935.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 18th instant, regarding the need of increased living accommodation for the Reverend Sisters in the teachers' residence on the Caughnawaga Reserve and the repairs that will be required to the building.

An officer of this Department will visit Caughnawaga in the near future and will look into the matter of the repairs required to the roof, the heating system and electric wiring.

Your obedient servant,

[F. Mackenzie, Secretary]

F. Brisebois, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

Ottawa, August 12, 1935.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, with reference to the account of the Shawinigan Water & Power Company for electricity used at the Sisters' residence during the month of June.

As previous accounts submitted show that the amount of electricity used during June is the smallest of any month in the year, the Department does not consider it fair to charge us on the average of the last twelve months. For the same period last year, we paid $2.20, and we are allowing a similar amount this year, which reduces the account you forwarded from $18.22 to $16.76.

As you are aware, due to the Company's own officials, a mistake was made in reading the meters last year, and, even though we were not responsible, the Department dealt fairly with the Company by paying the amount of arrears which they requested at that time. It is considered that the Company should check their meters and see that they are running properly. You may inform them that we are not prepared to allow any larger amount for the month of June than that mentioned in the first part of this letter. This matter should, therefore, be considered closed, with the payment made as indicated above.

Your obedient servant,

T. R. L. MacInnes,

Mr. J.D. Sutherland,

Dear Sir;

I met in Caughnawaga the nuns of the order of Ste. Anne, who teach the Indians. I understand their quarters are very cramped, and they have already asked for the building of a house which will shelter them more suitably. I understand also that they interviewed Mr. Phelan on the question.

I am happy to support the request, and I should be obliged if you would tell me if it will be possible to grant the building of a house where the nuns will be able to house comfortably the teaching staff of their communauté. I understand you are preparing the budget for your department. I hope you will be able to look after the matter.

Pray believe me,

Montreal, le 16 décembre 1935

Monsieur J.D. Sutherland,
Surintendent des Affaires Indiennes,
OTTAWA, Ont.

Cher monsieur,

J'ai rencontré, à Coughnawage, les religieuses de Ste-Anne qui donnent l'enseignement aux Indiens. Je comprends qu'elles sont bien à l'étroit dans la maison où elles logent et elles ont déjà demandé la construction d'une maison pouvant les loger convenablement. Je comprends également qu'elles ont eu des entrevues avec M. Phelan à ce sujet.

Il me fait plaisir d'appuyer cette demande, et je vous serais obligé de me dire si vous pouvez leur accorder la construction de cette maison où elles pourront loger convenablement le personnel enseignant de la communauté. Je comprends que vous êtes à préparer les crédits de votre département. J'espère que vous pourrez y pourvoir.

Veuillez me croire,
Votre tout dévoué,

Maxime Raymond

59 ouest rue St-Jacques,
Montréal.

MR/GS.
Ottawa, December 20, 1935.

Dear Mr. Raymond:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, regarding the erection of a new residence for the Reverend Sisters, teachers in the Indian schools on the Caughnawaga Reserve.

In this connection I have to say that the Department is aware of the unsatisfactory conditions existing in the present old residence. The question of the erection of a new residence is now under consideration, but I am unable to state, at present, whether funds for the purpose will be available in our Appropriation for the coming fiscal year. I can assure you, however, that the need of a new residence will not be lost sight of.

Yours very truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Maxime Raymond, Esq., M.P.,
59 St. James St. West,
Montreal, Que.

MEMORANDUM:

Deputy Minister

I am in receipt of Mr. Pratt's memorandum of November 29th, enclosing letters received from the General Superior of the Sisters of Sainte Anne, also from Mr. Maxime Raymond, M.P., requesting the erection of more suitable living quarters for the Reverend Sisters, who are teaching at the Caughnawaga R.C. Day School.

When the Reverend Sisters were first placed in charge of the Caughnawaga R.C. School about twenty years ago, the Department purchased from an Indian an old residence on the Reserve. As the attendance increased at the school it was necessary to engage the services of more sisters and from time to time additions have been added to the original building. At the present time there are fifteen sisters engaged at the Caughnawaga School and they utilize the services of two or three additional sisters as housekeepers. As a result, there are approximately seventeen or eighteen sisters residing in the sister's residence. As no additions have been made to the building within the past six years, the accommodation is quite limited. It should also be kept in mind that there is considerable fire hazard in the present building.

To erect a suitable residence for the sisters would involve an expenditure of $15,000. to $20,000. and no funds for this purpose have been provided in our estimates for the fiscal year 1938-39. This is a request that might receive careful and sympathetic consideration when preparing the estimates for the fiscal year 1939-40.

Director.

Montreal, December 30, 1937.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th inst., No. 5-1-8. My delay in answering has been caused by my desire to consult my colleagues of the Metropolitan Area with regard to conditions in the various urban municipalities of the Island of Montreal.

The Montreal Catholic School Commission pays $600.00 for the services of each female religious engaged in its schools. This is the general rate for all female religious under the jurisdiction of the Montreal Commission, including supervising principals and their assistants, as well as special teachers, such as domestic science instructors etc. An exception has been made in the case of the central high school for girls (Thomas D'Arcy McGee H.S., Girls' Section). In this school, the Principal receives $900.00 and each of the teachers, $700.00.

In most of the schools under the direction of religious orders, there are also a few lay teachers. The latter receive salaries according to the same scale which obtains in schools under lay direction. Boys' schools are directed by male religious or by lay teachers. Male religious principals receive $850.00, assistants and teachers, $650.00.

The Catholic School Commission of Westmount (School Municipality of St-Léon de Westmount) pays $575.00 to each female religious teacher and $675.00 to the Principal and her Assistant. In most of the other municipalities in the vicinity of Montreal, the rate is the same as in Montreal proper. In a few of the towns, the salary of the principal is $100.00 to $200.00 higher.
In all cases, the Commission provides a residence for the religious, with the number of rooms usually required in such houses, including chapel, common room, library etc. The School Commission pays for heat and light. Sometimes the religious are housed in a building belonging to their community. In such an event, the Commission pays rent to the religious congregation. If the residence is at some distance from the school, the school corporation assumes the cost of transportation.

These conditions are substantially the same in all the towns of the Montreal area, with very slight differences. Some local corporations assume the cost of certain other expenses, such as the wages of a cook, while others do not.

In Montreal (1935-36), the average number of pupils per classroom was 35.43. This information was derived from the printed Financial Report of the Montreal Catholic School Commission for the year 1935-36, the last available general record.

The average number of pupils per room in the Catholic schools of Verdun during the school year 1936-37 was 30.8 in the English classes and 35.7 in the French classes. This information was obtained from the local inspector.

The average number of pupils per room in the Catholic schools of Westmount during the school year 1936-37 was 21.3, or 26.4 in the English classes and 16.0 in the French classes. The small number of pupils per room in the French section, is due to the fact that the Commission provides a classroom for every grade and that the French-speaking pupils are in the minority. This information is from my own records.

The average number of pupils per classroom in your graded schools of Caughnawaga during 1936-37 was 30.3. However, at the time of my inspection visit to these schools, several pupils had left on account of illness or through moving away from the Reserve. The actual number of pupils per room, in attendance, was 27.0.

As a general rule, the Montreal Catholic School Commission requires the following numbers for the opening of new classrooms: 48 pupils for a Preparatory Class or 1st Grade, 40 for a 2nd or 3rd Grade, 35 for a 4th Grade, 30 for a 5th or 6th Grade, 25 for a 7th or 8th Grade or for a High School class. Of course, this rule cannot be applied to the letter; it must be adapted to local conditions, including the size of the rooms available. A new class is not opened unless the division of a class or classes will give a reasonable number of pupils for the new room. Classes, once opened are not closed unless the attendance drops too far below the required number.
I trust that the foregoing information will be of some use to your Department in the consideration of the request for a new teachers' residence for the Sisters at Caughnawaga. Their present living quarters are certainly far from adequate for the number of religious teachers engaged in your schools.

Your present scale of salaries for the religious teachers in your Caughnawaga schools is higher than the average paid to religious in the vicinity of Montreal. However, teachers' salaries are generally too low in Quebec at the present time. If I may be permitted to express a personal opinion, I respectfully suggest that this be borne in mind, as well as the fact that the Sisters in your schools are teaching boys and girls. In most of our boys' schools in the Province of Quebec, the teachers are Brothers or lay teachers, who receive higher remuneration than the Sisters.

Should you or some other representative of your Department be in Montreal, it would be a pleasure for me to confer with you or to obtain any information that you might consider useful in this or in any other matter pertaining to the good of your schools.

With the Season's Greetings and very best wishes for a Happy New Year,

I remain

yours sincerely,

A. E. Wescott,
Inspector of Schools.

Philip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Sir,

I beg to submit a report of my inspection of the Caughnawaga Reserve, made from April 5th to 12th, 1938.

I have also visited the Sisters residence. The building is inadequate to be used as a residence for the many teachers having to live there. Two bedrooms have no window on the outside; two other teachers have folding beds, one of them using the superior's office and the other one takes her bed into a hall next the kitchen. Memorandum:

DIRECTOR

Surveys & Engineering Branch

Re: Residence for teachers at the Caughnawaga R. C. Indian Day School.

In the year 1917 when the Reverend Sisters were first placed in charge of the Caughnawaga R. C. School the Department purchased a house from an Indian to serve as a Sisters' residence. Since that time the staff at the R. C. School has increased and as a result we have from time to time constructed additions to the original house.

At the present time we have 15 Reverend Sisters employed in the Caughnawaga R. C. School and there are also two or three Sisters to do the necessary house work. This means that approximately 18 persons are occupying this residence. For the last few years frequent complaints have been received from the Reverend Sisters regarding this building. I would appreciate it if you would arrange to have one of your architects visit Caughnawaga in the near future and inspect this building very carefully with a view to determining if the present residence could be remodelled in order to make the Reverend Sisters more comfortable or if a new teachers' residence should be erected on a different site. In either case the architect should let me have an estimate of the amount of expenditure that would be involved as we are considering providing funds for the purpose in the appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40. It is for this reason that I requested above that you arrange to have your architect visit Caughnawaga as soon as possible.

Director.
Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Teachers' residence,
Caughnawaga R.C. Indian
Day School.

With reference to your memorandum of the 16th instant, I may say that arrangements are being made for Mr. Harris to visit Caughnawaga Indian Reserve and make the inspection you request, with a view to preparing a report and estimate of cost, when he is returning from Nova Scotia in the near future.

Director.
Dear Sister Cleophas:

Mr. Harris, the architect of the Surveys & Engineering Branch who visited Caughnawaga recently, phoned me this morning and stated that you advised him that when you visited the Department a couple of years ago in connection with the proposed new teachers' residence you left some plans.

This morning I have reviewed our files very carefully and while I can find correspondence with reference to your visit I cannot find a trace of any plans or any statement of your requirements. I feel certain that if you left this with us at the time you came to Ottawa it would have been placed on file. If the plans were left loose in the office it would be impossible to locate them at the present time due to the fact that all the offices have been changed since that time and most of us are in new locations.

While we are by no means certain that we can secure a new residence for you during the coming fiscal year at the same time we are going to make another determined effort to secure the necessary funds.

I am sorry to trouble you but, as noted in the first part of this letter, if the plans that you mention were mislaid by us there is nothing that can be done about it now.

Rev. Sister Cleophas,
Principal,
R. C. Indian School,
Caughnawaga, Que.

(f) Any other rooms that you consider necessary

With this information the architects can prepare their own plans and estimate the cost.

With kind regards,

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan,

Caughnawaga, Que.,
January 20, 1940.

Dear Sir:

The Reverend Sister Superior has requested me to apply to the Department for six blankets for use of the Sisters.

It is stated that such a request has not been made since a long time and that the blankets requested are badly needed owing to the poor condition of the Residence.

Yours very truly,

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Dear Sir:-

I wish to inform you that the cooking stove in use at the Sister's residence is out of order and beyond repair. That stove has been in use for the last twenty-five years having been supplied to the Sisters when they first came to this Reserve to teach the Indian children.

It has been repaired many times but is now almost falling into pieces. It would be much appreciated if a new stove could be purchased to replace this old one and this, at your earliest convenience.

The stove has six lids and is of the ordinary type used only for cooking purposes. No waterfront is needed.

Yours very truly

Indian Agent

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
January 24, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 19th instant with reference to the cooking stove in the Sisters' residence at Caughnawaga. At the present time our funds are practically exhausted and it is, therefore, extremely doubtful if we can consider purchasing a new cook stove before the first of April.

However, you might let me have more detailed information regarding the stove required stating, if possible, a catalogue number. We require this information for the Purchasing Branch. When your reply is received further consideration will be given to the matter.

Regarding your letter of the 20th instant in which you state that the Rev. Sister Superior has requested 6 blankets I would point out that while formerly we did so the Department does not now supply such equipment. It will, therefore, be necessary for the Rev. Sisters to purchase these blankets from their own funds and, of course, in that event, the blankets will be their property.

Yours truly,

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent,

Teachers' Residence,
Chapleau, Oct. 25, 1940.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Here we are on another begging expedition! The roof on the teachers' residence has been more or less defective for the past few years. Mr. Robert has repaired it time and again with tar, etc., but it has reached such a point that he claims he can do nothing more.

Whenever we have a rainstorm, one sister is obliged to pick up her blankets and mattress and put up in the corridor. There is always a regiment of pallets and cots ready to be laid out in the said bedroom. For the same reason, the toilet room on the second floor cannot be used during bad weather.

Before snow comes in for the winter, we would ask you to approve the repairing of the roof. We would have just the absolutely necessary work done.

We are anxious for you to see our parlor and community room. What an improvement two coats of paint have done to this part of the house.

Once again, we thank you for all your kindness to us and we beg to remain

Respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Phillip Phelan,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
October 31, 1940.

Dear Sir:

The Department is in receipt of a letter from the Principal of the Caughnawaga R.C. School in which she states that the roof on the teachers' residence has been more or less defective for the past few years.

Our funds at the present time are extremely limited but I would like you to obtain, at the earliest possible date, an estimate of the cost of repairing the roof.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.
Dear Sir;-

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo in which you advise me that the Rev. Sister Superior of Caughnawaga complained of the bad condition of the roof of their residence.

As requested I obtained an estimate for its repairing, from Mr. I. Garand, Chateauguay Basin.

The price obtained is of $35.00 for the repairing of the roof with plastic cement and also its patching with tin where needed.

Yours very truly

Indian Agent

R.A. Hoey Esq.,
Supt., of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
November 12, 1940.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant you may incur an expenditure of $35.00 in repairing the roof of the Caughnawaga teachers' residence.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.

MEMORANDUM

March 20th, 1942.

Mr. Hoey,

Re: Residence for Rev. Sisters of Ste. Anne, Caughnawaga, Quebec.

With reference to the above, we have today been requested verbally by Mr. Phelan, to review two tenders obtained by Indian Agent Brisebois for work in connection with a new roof on the building.

For our information Mr. Phelan forwarded by messenger, Vol. 6 of your file 5-1-8, on which the tenders have been filed.

Our Architect has examined the tenders submitted with the Indian Agent's covering letter, dated the 13th instant, and reports as follows:

(a) That tenders were obtained from I. Garand, Roofing Contractor, Chateauguay Basin, Que., and J. Bte. Mathieu, Roofing Contractor, Beauharnois, Que.

(b) That tenders do not appear to be based on any particular type of workmanship or materials.

(c) That tenders differ with regard to the amount and character of work included.

(d) That totals of various items cannot be compared, and thus have no significance.

Under the circumstances, neither tender should be given consideration.

In this connection, I may say that if Indian Agents, when obtaining tenders on Departmental work, would advise your officers in detail regarding items upon which tradespeople are instructed to tender and also assure themselves that the work considered necessary is neither exceeded nor omitted by any tenderer, such action would establish a proper basis for comparison of tenders.

Plans with specifications or bills of material, prepared by this Service, as a basis for tendering would ensure uniformity of tenders, and can always be furnished within a reasonable time after complete information on the work is available.

In the present instance, it is recommended that action be deferred until a careful examination of the roof can be made by officers of this Service, and a specification of the work prepared.

Your file 5-1-8, Vol. 6, is returned herewith.

Encl.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Wardle.

Re: Residence for Rev. Sisters of Ste. Anne, Caughnawaga, Quebec.

With reference to the above, you are advised that on the 20th ultimo, this Service was requested verbally by officers of the Indian Affairs Branch to analyze two tenders which had been obtained by the Indian Agent at Caughnawaga for work on the roof of the building, which is the residence of the Reverend Sisters who teach school on the Reserve.

Upon examination, the tenders were found to have no basis for comparison as either the work included or its cost, and Mr. Hoey was advised that in our opinion further action on the matter should be deferred until our Architect was able to examine the roof and establish what work was required, and the best means of carrying it out.

Accordingly, Mr. Buck visited Caughnawaga on the 27th ultimo, and examined the roof in company with the Indian Agent.

Mr. Buck now reports as follows:

The teachers' residence is a building purchased by the Department about twenty-five years ago, to which it appears a rear wing has at some time been added.

An interior examination of ceilings and upper walls confirmed complaints that roof leakages exist in numerous places, and plaster and decorating show damage.

The flat roof over the original portion of the building is of built-up felt and gravel, while the flat roof of the rear wing is metal covered. Points in the vicinity of the leaks have been repaired, but the felt and gravel roof is decomposing, and the metal covered area is corroding through at many points. The perished condition of all roof covering is of long standing, since moisture discharges from broken roofing blisters and rust spots can be produced by foot pressure. It is evident that considerable roof boarding is decayed, and it will likely be found that some of the structural members are in the same condition.

It is apparent that general maintenance on the building has been neglected, and a considerable amount of repair and replacement work could be carried out to advantage, particularly to the exterior; but it is understood the Indian Affairs Branch wish to restrict consideration of immediate expense to the roof, consequently detailed information on other items was not prepared.

J.M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Under the circumstances outlined, therefore, it is recommended that all the existing roofing material should be removed and replaced by a new five-ply bonded roof covering, the cost of which would be based on a specification prepared by this Service covering the necessary labour and materials, and upon which competitive tenders could be invited.

It is estimated that the cost of the work, including supervision expenses, would be in the neighbourhood of $800.00.

Unless advised to the contrary, it is proposed to prepare a specification and call for tenders on the work as soon as possible.

Respectfully submitted,

Chief Engineer.
April 23rd, 1942.

Caughnawaga, Que.,

Dear Sir;-

The Sister Superior of the sisters of St. Anne, at Caughnawaga, called at this office today and complained that the condition at their residence has become intolerable due to the leakage of the roof. She stated that during the recent heavy rains they were greatly inconvenienced.

The Superior also requested me to ask that the veranda on the front and on the west side of the residence be repaired or made anew as it is in bad condition. She asked that the residence be re-painted as she claims that this has not been done for the past eight or nine years.

While at the office the Principal brought up the subject of the chemical toilet which was recently supplied for use of the teachers at the Eastern School. She stated that they did not intend to use it as it is not what was supposed to have been supplied, as this one has to be emptied every other month by the janitors.

Relative to this chemical toilet I wish to say that the salesman of Thomas Robertson was requested to call at the school, through the Raymond Hardware Co., before the purchase was made in order to advise as to the suitable type of toilet to be supplied, taking into consideration the number of persons who would use it etc.,. When it was explained that there are only six teachers who are there during the school hours, he recommended the purchase of the one delivered, stating that this type would amply meet the need; hence its purchase.

The Superior is and was under the impression that the toilet to be supplied would cost about $200.00 and would be of the regular type which empties in a septic tank.

Relative to the roof the Sisters would appreciate if that work could be started on or about the 28th instant, as they leave on that date for ten days, going for their annual retreat.

Yours very truly,

22nd July, 1942.

Memorandum:

Dr. McGill

Re: Teachers' Residence, Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Caughnawaga, Que.

With further reference to my memorandum of April 23rd last and to your reply thereto of April 27th, I may say that on looking into the matter further it has been decided that it would be very advisable to put a new roof on the one-storyed sun room used by the teachers. This work is in addition to what was covered in my memorandum of April 23rd and together with certain repairs, the full extent of which cannot be determined until the work is actually being done, will increase the cost by possibly some $500 in addition to the $800 mentioned in my memorandum.

As this additional work has been discussed and tentatively agreed upon with officers of your Branch, unless you advise us to the contrary we will proceed to accept a bid of $1,235.50 submitted by Isaie Garand, of Chateauquay, P.Q., with the further understanding that -

1. Our officer supervising the work should be authorized to establish with the Contractor the unit cost per f.b.m. in place and the extent of work at such cost that may be found necessary in the roof structure when exposed.

2. That funds covering the total cost of the work be transferred to this Service by Indian Affairs Branch as soon as the extent of necessary repair work on the roof structure is established.

Director.
Ottawa,
July 27, 1942.

Dear Sir,

On the 18th ultimo we wrote you outlining our problems in connection with changing from oil to coal burning equipment at the Morley Indian Hospital, Morley, Alberta, and at the Caughnawaga Teachers' Residence. In the former case, the alterations required are extensive, costly, and will take considerable time.

On the 6th instant we sent you forms F.O. 4 and 4 A duly filled out showing annual requirements for each institution. An early decision is requested in order to give us sufficient time to make the required alterations and installations if necessary.

Yours very truly,

C. W. JACKSON
Deputy Minister

Toronto, Ont.
Dear Sir:

I wish to refer to previous correspondence dealing with the heating of the Sisters Residence and to request to be advise if it is the intention to have the grates installed, for coal heating, in the near future or before the furnace is put into operation? We still have a sufficient quantity of oil to last about two months. It is the intention to have this oil used at heating the residence or should it be turned over to a dealer.

If the changing of the furnace from oil heating to coal heating takes place at the beginning of the winter it may be that the residence will not be heated for one or one and a half day, pending the installation of the grates etc.,. Kindly let me have your views in the matter.

Yours very truly

Indian Agent

Re: Heating facilities,
Teacher's Residence, Caughnawaga

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, in which you seek departmental instructions in respect to the heating equipment that should be installed in the teacher's residence.

The records here indicate that the Chief Executive Assistant communicated with the Oil Controller a few weeks ago with respect to this matter. I regret to state, however, that at this date no reply has been received. In view of announcements that have recently appeared in the Press, I am hopeful that we shall be permitted to continue with the consumption of fuel oil. I shall communicate with you again in respect to this matter, just as soon as a definite ruling has been received by this Branch.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, September 5, 1942.

Dear Mr. Morgan:

I must express regret that I did not discuss with you, at the time of my visit to your office a few days ago, a number of urgent requests that have reached this Branch in respect to the consumption of fuel oil at the Caughnawaga teachers' residence on the Caughnawaga Reserve, Que.

I note from the files that this matter was brought to your attention by the Deputy Minister in letters dated July 18 and August 15, 1942.

The Caughnawaga teachers' residence is an old stone building which, had it not been for the years of depression and the outbreak of war, would have been replaced by a new building. At present it provides accommodation for 16 teachers. These teachers belong to the religious Order of St. Ann and the building is, in many respects, convenient. We have at present in the small basement an oil tank and an oil burning furnace. It will be necessary to remove this tank in order to secure space for coal and it will be necessary, also, to reconstruct the furnace. No provision has been made in our estimates of this year for the money necessary for these alterations. In addition to this, the Nuns will no doubt resent the presence of a caretaker in the building, whose presence will be necessary to look after the coal burning furnace. In view of this fact, I am convinced that should we decide to burn coal this year we will be compelled to revert again to the burning of oil just as soon as the supply of oil for this purpose is available. I naturally hesitate to undertake these alterations and incur this expense, to meet a condition that appears to be temporary. Would it be possible for you to review this request and let us have a decision at an early date?

May I embrace this opportunity to thank you very sincerely for the permission granted us for the use of fuel oil at the Indian hospital, Morley, Alberta?

Yours very truly,

(sgd.) H. W. McGill,
Director.

A. S. Morgan, Esq.,
Office of the Oil Controller,
Department of Munitions and Supply,
15 King Street West,
Toronto, Ont.
Ottawa, September 24, 1942.

Re: Heating of Sisters' Residence,
Caughnawaga R. C. Day School

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of August 28, in which you sought information in respect to the marginally-noted subject.

Although we have been in constant communication with the Oil Controller, the chances of securing the oil sufficient for this purpose appear to be exceedingly remote. I am disposed to think that you should allow the Sisters to consume the oil now on hand and make provision for the adjustments necessary to start heating the residence with coal at a later date. It is just possible that a little inconvenience may be caused to the Sisters while these adjustments are being made. However, I cannot see how this can be avoided. You might let us know in due course the amount of coal that will be necessary for this purpose.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.
Dr. H. W. McGill,
Director of Indian Affairs,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

We have your letter of September 5th dealing with Caughnawaga Teachers' Residence.

Here again we are placed in a most difficult position since we have prohibited the use of fuel oil for the heating of all convents and institutions etc., and while it may be a difficult matter for you to obtain the necessary funds, I am sure you will readily appreciate that if we granted an exemption in this case we would be asked to afford the same treatment in many other instances where the conversion is a very difficult and costly matter.

We would urge you, therefore, to investigate this matter and see if it is not possible for you to convert to some alternative means of firing.

Very truly yours,

A. S. Morgan,
Executive Assistant to the Oil Controller.

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer you to Mr. Hoey's letter of September 24, in connection with heating the Sisters' residence at the Caughnawaga R.C. Day School. As intimated in that letter, it will be impossible to secure sufficient oil to heat the building during the current winter. I am not certain how long the quantity of oil at present on hand will last, but presume it will soon be finished. You should, therefore, let me know at once the amount of coal that will be required.

Have you secured the grates which you stated in your letter of August 6 you could obtain from the Raymond Hardware Company?

An immediate reply would be appreciated.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. F. Brisebois,
Indian Agent,
Caughnawaga, Que.
Caughnawaga, Que.,
November 9, 1942.

Dear Sir;-

I wish to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 3rd instant dealing with the heating of the Sister's residence at Caughnawaga.

In reply I wish to say that the oil in store is presently being used for the heating of the building and that the quantity on hand will likely last until the end of December or the beginning of January.

It is estimated that about 12 tons of stove coal will be needed for the balance of the winter at that place.

The grates have been ordered and will be delivered within two weeks of this date.

Yours very truly,

Phillip Phelan, Esq.,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Memorandum:

Re: Teachers' Residence, Caughnawaga Indian Agency, Quebec.

Further to our memorandum of the 31st ultimo in connection with a reported leakage in the roof of the above, you are advised that the roof has been inspected by the Indian Agent in the company of the contractor who installed the new roof last year.

It was found that the new roof had been pierced in one place, seemingly as a result of an ice laden branch falling from an adjacent tree, on the exact spot where the leak developed, during a severe sleet storm last winter.

While the contractor was under no obligation to repair such damage without charge, the Indian Agent reports that the small leak was repaired by the contractor at no expense to the Department. Indian Agent Brisebois further reports that inspection after heavy rains shows that no further leakage has occurred.

Chief Engineer

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

I have your letter of the 20th instant, regarding the refrigerator at the Caughnawaga R.C. teachers' residence. While neither the company's letter of October 18 nor their letter of January 18 is exactly clear, we are now under the impression that the unit which the company installed was only intended to remain at the Caughnawaga School temporarily and that, if they remove it now, the refrigeration equipment will be useless. On the other hand it might be inferred from the company's letter of the 18th instant that they only wish to recondition the unit and would be prepared to install it again in the refrigerator.

The first alternative would require the purchase of a new coil at an approximate cost of $355.00. Neither at the present time nor in the immediate future can the Department hold out any hope that authority can be obtained for the purchase of this.

If the second alternative is correct, it would only be a matter of your interviewing the Principal of the school, as it would simply mean that the Sisters would be without the use of the refrigerator for a few weeks and possibly this is the best time of the year to have this happen.

Caughnawaga, April 24, 1944.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

We wish to tell you all our gratitude for obtaining relief from the condition brought about by the burning of the heating unit in the teachers' residence. The new unit is now installed and the house is comfortable.

It seems that everything collapses at the same time. May I call your attention again to the condition of our ice-box? This morning, I was called to the kitchen and sister showed me all she was obliged to throw away because of lack of refrigeration. Much of the $12.00 order of meat brought in on Saturday, was unfit for use and so many other things. This has happened so often of late. It seems a shame that food goes to waste when so many are suffering from hunger in the world today.

You promised that you would see to it last October and again in January, you wrote Mr. Brisebois that Mr. Doucet would take the necessary steps on his next visit. Mr. Doucet has been here twice since then. He has examined the box and has admitted that it is useless to expect any more service from it. It was installed some twenty years ago. Are we too exacting?

We feel certain that you are going to do all you can for us and we thank you for it and for so many other kindnesses of which we have benefited in the past.

Respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

We regret the delay in answering your letters of July 7th and 19th re the refrigeration equipment on order for the teachers' resident at Caughnawaga. The Condensing unit has been in our hands for over a month but we have had difficulty in getting delivery of the evaporator from the manufacturer.

Today we have received, from the Manufacturer, the way-bill covering the evaporator so we should be able to complete this installation in a matter of a few days.

Yours very truly

McParland Refrigeration Reg'd.

[Signature]

Manager.

TGM/mm
The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

The outside stairs at the back of the Teachers' Residence recently gave away slightly injuring two persons who were going out of the building. This stair was a wooden one and has to be made anew as the wood was all rotted.

As this stair has to be replace I would suggest that it be made with cement. The following material would be required;—5 bags of cement, 1 ton of sand also one load of crushed stone. The work to be done free of charge by the Janitor.

I would appreciate receiving your authorization in order that this work be done as soon as possible.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 12, 1944.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

It is noted the work will be done by the janitor.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

MEMORANDUM:

November 2, 1945.

Re: Teachers' Residence, Caughnawage Indian Agency, Quebec.

Attached for transmission to the Indian Affairs Branch are 4 sets of black-line prints, (Index 804, Sheets P1 to P5 inclusive) of preliminary sketch drawings for the above, as well as 2 blue prints of a block plan, (Index 811, Sheet LP,) showing a possible arrangement of new buildings on the site formerly occupied by the Senior School, destroyed by fire in December, 1941.

It will be seen from the Block Plan, that proposed buildings on the site are:-

(a) The 12 Classroom School, of which sketches were forwarded to you under date of August 26th last.

(b) The Teachers' Residence, of which prints are attached.

(c) A Boiler House, sketches of which will not be prepared until approval has been received for the other buildings, and the site has been surveyed and further investigated.

With reference to the attached preliminary sketches of the proposed Teachers' Residence, our design shows a building with two stories and partial basement. The structural frame would be of reinforced concrete, with exterior walls of brick and tile. Interior partitions are intended to be of gypsum or terra cotta tile construction, and the whole interior finished in painted plaster.

As will be seen on examination, accommodation has been provided for a staff of 20, with necessary kitchen and dining room space, and toilet facilities. A large common room and two reception rooms on the lower floor provide space for off-duty activities. A one storey wing at the rear of the building houses the chapel.

The building is intended to be heated by steam from a central plant which could also serve the new school. It is estimated to cost in the neighborhood of $60,000.00

The sketches are submitted for examination by the interested officers of the Indian Affairs Branch, and doubtless a number of changes will be required before working drawings are undertaken.

Encls.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

T. S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.
Ottawa, December 1, 1945.

Rev. Sister Mary George, Principal, Caughnawaga R.C.
Indian Day School, Caughnawaga, Quebec.

Enclosed please find a circular on water softener. It would be necessary before you decide on what capacity, to have the water in your well analysed. I believe that the Crane Company do this type of work and would be only too pleased to have this done for you. It would be necessary to send to them one quart of water for a sample.

Trusting that this is what you have been looking for. I remain,

Yours truly,

A.J. Doucet
Training Division.

Date: July 12th, 1948
Dear Sir,

We wish to extend our most heartfelt thanks for the beautiful new typewriter we have just received. Our teachers are much pleased with it and wish to convey their appreciation for this useful object which will be at their disposal now. We are pleased to note also that the Department has begun to fill out our requisition for we have already received several articles.

We are enclosing a copy of our programme for our Commencement Exercises. Mr. Hoey's letter held a promise of a visit from you or Mr. Phelan on June nineteenth. We were disappointed not to see you then. No doubt some pressing work must have prevented you from coming.

We thank you also for authorizing the painting of the second floor of our residence. May we draw your attention to the fact that many of our teachers are away during the month of July and therefore this would be the most appropriate time to have the work done. Would it be possible to hasten the Purchasing Department about the paint required for this work? We have just sent the required quotations for the library, the phonograph and the mixer which we requisitioned in May. We trust the prices will be accepted or that at least something equivalent will be sent to us.

We hope that the summer months will bring you a pleasant and restful vacation.

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Ottawa, Ont.
July 16, 1948.

Reverend and dear Sister:

We have your letter of the 12th instant and are pleased to know that you are satisfied with the typewriter that you have been supplied.

It is regretted that none of our officials were able to attend your commencement exercises. During that week I was inspecting the schools in the St. Regis Agency.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Sister Mary Albertus,
Principal,
Caughnawaga R.C. Day School,
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.,

Mr. Viau, Manuel Training Teacher, at the local Schools, has on this date requested this office to communicate with you in order to advise that the owner of his residence, Mr. Arthur Beauvais, is not willing to allow the installation of a heat register in the ceiling of the kitchen in order that the room above same be properly heated.

Mr. Viau is suggesting that the Branch allows him to purchase two electric heaters to install in the upstairs room in view of the attitude of the owner of the house.

Mr. Viau also requested to be supplied with an electric washing machine. He claims that his own washing machine is now out of order and beyond repairs.

Electric heaters are always a costly proposition and it might be preferable to supply the teacher with a small oil heater as this will only be used to supplement the downstairs heater. Small size heaters could be obtained locally at the following prices, Coleman $72.95, Silent Glow $49.50 and a Portable heater for $39.50.

Please let me have your views in the above.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Supt., Indian Agency,

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources, Ottawa, Ont.

I wish to refer to your letter of the 15th ultimo authorizing the purchase of an oil heater for use at the residence of Mr. Visu, Manual Teacher of the local Schools and in this connection to say that one heater, Coleman, slightly used was purchased for him on this Reserve from an Indian who was not using same any longer, having changed to coal. This heater is in first class condition and gives entire satisfaction. Price paid $40.00 instead of $72.95.

May I say that the difficulty encountered to heat Mr. Visu's residence properly is due to the fact that the circulation of the heat is poor.

In order to boost the circulation of the air it is suggested that an electric fan be obtained. This it is believed would improve the situation, as it has done at the Agency office.

A fan could be obtained for approximately $15.00, locally. In view of the fact that there has been a saving effected in the purchase of the oil heater, it is recommended that a fan be purchased, as it will no doubt give satisfaction.

(Fr. Brisebois)

MEMORANDUM.

As instructed I went over to Caughnawaga on the morning of the 1st instant in company with Mr. Agent Blain. We drove to the office, where a number of Indians were waiting for Mr. Blain. Chief Councillor Dailabont was there and I suggested that we should meet at 1 P.M. and discuss the plans of the new school it is proposed to erect in the Village. In the interval I called on Father Granger. He was in Montreal on Business, but his assistant promised to attend the meeting, which was held in the Boy's School, the office being too small and the Council Chamber too cold.

At 1 P.M. the Agent, Priest, Councillors and 75 members of the Band were present, J. W. Josks acting as interpreter. I showed and explained to them the plans and we discussed them and the site. The majority of the Indians were against a graded school, while Father Granger and some of the most intelligent members of the Band advocated having two schools, one for the girls and one for the boys, as at present. Miss Howlett is also in favour of this arrangement. She has lived on the Reserve for the past six years and is competent to express an opinion as she has been in charge of the Girl's School and knows the feeling of the Indians as regards the co-education of the sexes. While the graded school at Pierreville is a great success under the Grey Nuns I doubt if it would be suited to Caughnawaga even if the objections I have mentioned were overcome. The Indians as a whole are not so far advanced and not so anxious for the education of their children.

Father Granger told me that the co-education of
the sexes is contrary to the rules of his Order, and it would not be politic to go counter to the rules of the Jesuits, who have charge of the Mission of Caughnawaga.

The plans I had with me provided for separate rooms for the boys and girls, with separate entrances, but this was objected to for much the same reason by the Priest, who wished the sexes to be kept apart. There would also be the question of the teacher's priority and authority, which would likely lead to trouble.

After carefully considering the question I am of opinion that separate schools for the boys and girls of the Village should be continued.

The site of the present school would allow of no provision for play grounds, as it is only 175 feet by 100 feet, with the Lock-up in the middle of the lot at the rear.

The Indians were in favour of a site which would give room for a large play ground and suggested that a portion of the common near the new cemetery should be chosen. I walked out there with Mr. DeLisle, the head teacher of the Boys' School, and Constable Twoaxe. There is plenty of room and the ground is high and dry and could be easily drained. It is at the back of the Village, about half a mile in rear of the Main street. It was raining hard and the road was breaking up and could not be worse at any season of the year, but I did not find any of the streets in the Village in a better condition, and I think that, if it is decided to build two schools, it would be well suited for the Boys' School. The Girls' School would then be put up on the present school site, which is the best that could be found, being in the centre of the Village opposite the Church and roomy enough.

The adoption of the proposal to have two schools
on the sites referred to, which are indicated on the accompanying blue prints of the Village, would in my opinion satisfy all concerned.

MEMORANDUM:

In compliance with instructions I visited Caughnawaga on Wednesday and Thursday, last, for the purpose of inspecting the sites suggested for the new Boys' School, the contract for which has been let. Three different sites were suggested, one near the cemetery, one No. 460, the property of Mr. Jackson, on the cemetery road, and one on the main road in the village, lot No. 687.

A great many of the Indians object to the cemetery site on account of the distance from the main part of the village and I think myself that their objection is well founded. The distance, especially in winter, would be objectionable and the road leading to this site is in very bad condition; in fact the Department would have to spend considerable money in providing a culvert and filling in for a considerable distance where the road at present is very low and subject to floods in the spring time.

Lot No. 687 on the main road has good frontage, but some fifty feet from the street there is a sudden slope and
the back part of the lot is quite low, the level being perhaps some eight feet below that of the front of the lot.

The portion of the common at the rear which, it was suggested, could be used in conjunction with this lot for a play ground, etc., is very low and stony. Moreover, this lot is at present in liquidation, it being one of the parcels of land which are being sold by Mr. Jacobs, Curator of the Estate of Mr. Montour, insolvent. The sale has, I understand, been postponed by order of the Department for a week and I anticipate that there will be considerable delay before the title of Mr. Montour to all of this property, which is to be sold by the order of the Superior Court, is established.

Mr. Jackson's lot is situated on the cemetery road, 185 feet from the main street. It contains approximately an acre and is, in my opinion, a very favourable site. I should have preferred a site on the main street had a suitable one been available, but this is so close to the street that, except in so far as the view is concerned, there could be no serious objection. This piece of land will provide ample play grounds, something that is wanting at the other two schools in the village.

I was very much pleased with the two new buildings which were erected last year. It seems too bad that buildings
of this class should be erected where there is hardly even a piece of ground for a blade of grass to grow. The surroundings detract very much from the general appearance of the buildings.

The Council meets today and it may be that a resolution to that effect will be passed. In any event I think that it is advisable for the Department to purchase this lot rather than to take the free site at the cemetery.

MEMORANDUM:

When the choice for the Caughnawaga Boys' School site was made there was, to my mind, one objection. It is this; on the corner adjoining the lot there is a stable which greatly blocks the view of the school from the main street. It would be an improvement if this stable could be moved to the other side of the lot upon which it is situated. The owner is a widow who keeps a small grocery store and while there would be some disadvantage to her, as she would have to make a driveway through her lot and thus lose some of her garden space, I think if she would agree to a reasonable sum the Department should negotiate with her to have the building removed. The accompanying sketch will show the situation of the building.

It will be necessary to supply water for the Boys' School and we have recently drilled at the Protestant School and struck water at twenty-five feet. As there is a short distance between the two sites I presume we would have no difficulty in finding water at the Boys' School and
it might be well to have the drilling undertaken at once.

At a band meeting this 16th day of August, 1915, at the Council Chamber at the Caughnawaga reserve, in the presence of four Councillors viz: Joel Leger, Philisle, Mitchell Morino and Peter Jacobs, and the unanimous demand of over 100 male Citizens of the age over 21, it was unanimously resolved that the flag staff stand of the Village situate in the Common just in front of the Village Church be re-erected and that the proposed fencing of a certain part of the said Common in enlargement of the School grounds be hereby protested to the Government, and that Mitchell Morino and Peter Jacobs are hereby appointed to notify the persons who are engaged in erecting the said fence, to desist in constructing the said fence as to enclose any part of the said common property of the band, but that the fence be made in perpetuance and on the same lines as previously constructed, or until that time that the question be fully and legally submitted to the Band concerned.

A Copy of this to be sent to the Dept intimating the action of the band.

The petition of John Skye and John Simpson, both Indians of Caughnawaga, respectfully sheweth:

1.- On Saturday last, the 21st of August Inst., a copy of a resolution passed by the Band of the Iroquois Indians of the Caughnawaga Reserve, has been sent and must have been received by you. (copy of said resolution is herewith annexed).

2.- By said resolution it is shown that a part of the "common" of Caughnawaga which has been in open and in peaceable possession of the Tribe since over a hundred years, has been taken without any color of rights and without any notice to the Council of the Tribe to that effect, by certain persons pretending to have had power from your Department to do so, and a fence has been erected around said territory, thereby not only doing away with said common, but encroaching upon public road.

3.- A flag staff which has been erected by the Tribe, and continuously replaced since the year 1788, has also been taken down without any right and without notice.

4.- The Indians of Caughnawaga humbly sheweth by the undersigned, that said "common" is the only public ground that they possessed in the center of the village of Caughnawaga; that it is the only meeting place, and they resent very much the action of certain individuals, who pretending that they are acting under the authority of your Department have taken illegally possession of the said land.

5.- In the name of justice which should be given to them as to any other subjects of the Crown, they claim that no person whatever had any right to dispossess them of the land that they absolutely need for the common benefit of the Tribe.
Wherefor your Petitioners humbly ask from you that you should investigate the matter and render to them the justice to which they are entitled, in giving orders that all works about the erection of a fence around the land known as the common, situated in front of the church of the village of Caughnawaga, should be stopped and things put back in the same estate as they were before, leaving to the Tribe the use of said land.

And your Petitioners will ever pray.

Caughnawaga, 23 August 1915.

When the fence was placed where it is at present, the boundary marks of the Government land were observed, and no one is suffering from it. If by your decision this fence is removed, it will give to these recalcitrant Indians an importance that they have not, and it will create a precedence that will always cause much annoyance to the agent. I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of a recent letter from the agent, concerning the future location of the new school to be erected in the Village of Campbell's Bay.

There is also a slight depression on lot 85 which could easily be filled with the surrounding stone. This stone which seems to be common on the site could easily be used for the foundations of the new building, as well as to build the fence which will need to be erected around the school grounds. It might appear expensive to acquire such a quantity of ground, costing close to $60, but I believe the suggested ground is the most appropriate, being a good place with a large play ground for the children, if the land is suitable to the purpose.

construction by the Department was intended for a school or of a convent. Ottawa, April 7th, 1927.

Dear Sir:-

I have learned from Mr. Indian Agent Letourneau, of St. Constant, Que., that you are not disposed to sell your interest in Lot No. 95 in the Village of Caughnawaga. I wish to inform you that the Department is taking over Lots 85 and 92 to 95, inclusive, for school purposes and we are compensating the Indian occupants for their interest. The intention is to erect a large day school building on Lots 85 and 93 and to use the remainder of the property for playground purposes. The top floor of the new building is to be an auditorium and will be used for general meetings, as well as for school concerts, closing exercises, etc. Further, the playground will be open to the Caughnawaga Indians for organized sport.

I am sure that, when you understand the nature of the Department's plans and wishes, you will be glad to dispose of your interest in Lot 95. I am prepared to make a fair offer and, in view of the price that we have paid for Lots 92 and 93, I shall be glad to arrange a payment of $275 for your equity in Lot 95 if you will take the necessary affidavit that you are the holder of the lot and sign a Quit Claim.

May I point out that it is advisable for you to accept this fair offer for your interest, as Section 11A of the Indian Act gives the Governor-in-Council power to take the land of an Indian, held under location ticket or otherwise, for school purposes. If we cannot agree on the compensation to be paid, the Superintendent General of this Department has power to make arrangements for the determination of the amount to be paid.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean.

Dear Mr. Beauvais:

I am desirous that you should know something of the Department's plans in connection with the new school building to be erected this year at Caughnawaga. An item for the purpose in the Appropriation for Indian Education has been allowed by Parliament and I am hopeful that building activity will commence in a few weeks. It is the intention to erect a two-story school building. In the basement, there will be domestic science and manual training rooms as well as the ordinary facilities. On the first floor, there will be five classrooms and on the top floor, a large auditorium. I intend that this auditorium shall be used as a community hall whenever the requirements call for its use for such purpose.

The site selected is Lots 85 and 93 and I am also arranging for a large playground on Lots 92, 94 and 95. I intend to have this playground available for general athletic purposes in the evenings and on holidays, whenever it is not required for school children.

It is my wish that these facts become generally known on the reserve. I understand there has been a rumor that the building was a convent with residential quarters; but, of course, this is not the case.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott
Deputy Superintendent General.

Memorandum:

DA. SCOTT.

Perhaps the most important subject discussed on Tuesday evening, last, with the Caughnawaga Indian Council was the question of instruction by male teachers in the case of the older boys. I firmly stated that, as far as the regular work was concerned, the Department was quite satisfied with the present arrangements and that they would not be disturbed. A physical drill instructor has been appointed, who will no doubt instill manly habits into the older boys.

The question of vocational training under a qualified male instructor or instructors grew out of this discussion, and I am satisfied that something along this line should be done as soon as funds could be found for the purpose. I believe we should arrange classes in manual training and work preparatory to the structural steel vocation. I am of the opinion that a building should be rented and one instructor secured, so that the activity could be given a trial.

Those older boys who can no longer be benefitted by the regular academic work and all those that have left our regular schools should be eligible for enrolment in this vocational training work. If the work develops, still older boys might be taken in when they were without work and night classes might be given, so that those who were working could benefit. If the scheme proved a success it might be necessary in a few years to erect a small building for this purpose.

Supt. of Indian Education.

My dear Sir,

I take the liberty in writing you today to make known to the Department the conditions of the upper class room at Kateri School that has been chosen by the Councillors, I believe, for Manual Training.

You are aware that owing to the half windows, the light is very poor and when art tables are placed on the stage it will be quite dark; the pupils who sit below the stage will be obliged to work by the electric light all day.

The Agent has left it to the Councillors to find a suitable place to carry on that activity, but they want one of the schools and their intention is to overcrowd the upper class of Kateri school so as to obtain the Auditorium of the Senior School.

Why not rent Delormier's dance hall that is closed? It is a spacious room that could be used with advantage, I think, for night school. Mr. Cloud's house, formerly our school, is not rented, and others also could be had.

I wish to impress upon the Department that I would be only too glad to co-operate in every way possible to encourage those who want to follow the evening courses and open wide the doors of Kateri and Eastern Schools if we had sufficient room for the equipment required.

I can hardly believe that the new Auditorium will ever be used for that purpose. I am, my dear Sir,
