Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 26th instant I beg to say that on the evening of the 28th I have visited the vocational training class at Caughnawaga. Four pupils were present at the beginning and four others arrived about half an hour later. Their age appears to average 17 years.

As to the question whether the instruction were more practical and less theoretical, is I believe, one that might be differently appreciated. I have no doubt that there may be a large number of young Indians that do not know how to read a plan while they could be a better steel worker than another who, with a plan into his hand, succeeds in the framing up of a steel work. In such case, it would require the equipment of a steel structure contractor for the teaching, in a practical way, to that class of pupils.

I believe in theoretical way of teaching to the young Indians for the reason that if they intend to manage the construction of a steel work they must understand the plan which is submitted for this purpose, otherwise, they would have to work under the supervision of others, in a practical way.

I would recommend that not more than eight, or ten at the most, young Indians be selected by the instructor for the study and drawing of plans, such study being to be made clear and the least possible complicated.

Out of a number of thirty pupils, for instance, we would probably find two or three among them who may have some good disposition as draftmen; a few others might understand a plan while they have no aptitude as draftmen; the remaining number could be more or less practical providing that they be working under the supervision of a "tenderfoot" who, in a theoretical way, is standing alongside the proposed steel structure with a plan into his hand.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Mr. Letourneau,

I have carefully looked over the papers forwarded on the 4th inst. and trust I have correctly grasped the meaning of their contents, namely:

1st. that Mr. Mullins is teaching night school to young boys still attending our schools.

2nd. that we are indirectly asked to set aside our established program (based on the plan of the Montreal School Board) to suit the needs of Mr. Mullins' night school.

After having read your communication, my first step was to procure the names of those attending the night-classes and from the register kept for that purpose, I extracted the enclosed roll. It was quite a revelation to find that the names of boys even in the 3rd. and 4th. Year figure on this list. If the grievance made by the Caughnawaga Council concerned pupils who had left our Graduating Class, we would find the complaint legitimate, but when boys, regardless of age and grade are freely admitted, even dullards and hopeless cases, we think the attack made on our Arithmetic program lacks justice as well as logic.

Night-schools are generally opened for the working boy, and not for the boy who is attending school and who has plenty of homework to do without seeking for more elsewhere.

No person of common sense will expect boys in the 3rd. 4th. or 5th. grades, etc., who put in application to be-
members of the night school, to possess the same amount of knowledge as the 8th Year Graduate. Hence, if our school children are accepted at the night classes, let them be taken as they are; a child is a child and, with few exceptions, must not, and cannot go beyond the program laid out for its age and grade, by wise and experienced people.

Perhaps instead of our Arithmetic program handicapping Mr. Mullins, it may be that the presence of our school boys is handicapping the progress of those who left school some years back and who now desire to continue their studies. If so, why allow the presence of school children to impede their progress? Still, Mr. Mullins seems to favor the younger ones since the tables in the Council Room were all lowered in order to give them more comfort and convenience.

And again, perhaps our Arithmetic program is not totally to blame for lack of progress. As you are already aware, discipline is a powerful factor in a classroom. Now, is discipline always at par in the above mentioned night school? Unless I have been misinformed, I believe there is space not only for improvement in that line, but reformation as well.

Trusting you will feel that we are doing justice to our pupils with regard to Arithmetic, I remain,

Cordially yours,

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. L. Letourneau,
St. Constant, Que.

Ottawa, June 2, 1932.

Sir:

I wish to refer to earlier correspondence regarding the possibility of discontinuing the use of the council hall for the evening manual training classes at Caughnawaga. Would you make careful enquiries with a view to determining whether other accommodation can be secured for this work? The Department is not prepared to allow the auditorium in the senior school to be used for this activity, but I do believe we should seriously consider setting aside one of the rooms in the basement of this building. It could be locked off from the rest of the building and a separate entrance could be arranged. Does this proposal commend itself to you?

It has also been brought to my attention that the attendance at these evening classes during the month of May has materially decreased. You will please inform the members of the Band at the next council meeting that, unless the parents and young men show more interest in this special and rather costly activity, the Department will have to seriously consider discontinuing it.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Monsieur,

J'ai l'honneur d'accuser réception de votre lettre du 2 courant et en réponse de vous informer qu'après avoir examiné les salles de récréation au sous-sol de l'école Senior, je crois que ce projet d'en disposer une à l'enseignement du dessin est pratique. J'en ai causé avec la Reverend Soeur Supérieure qui, quoiqu'hésitante, semblerait cependant vouloir en faire le sacrifice.

J'ai aussi parlé de ce projet à l'instituteur M. J.G. Mullins, qui suggère que ce changement ne soit pas fait avant le mois de septembre prochain pour la raison qu'il ne lui reste plus que quatre séances de dessin pour compléter la présente année scolaire. Subsequently, les institutrices de l'école Senior m'ont informé que ces salles leur sont particulièrement utiles en fin d'année scolaire.

Finalement, à leur assemblée d'hier soir j'ai soumis le cas aux membres du Conseil de Caughnawaga qui conviennent bien que ce changement ne peut pas facilement se faire avant l'ouverture de la prochaine année scolaire. Consequentement, je vous prie de bien vouloir ajourner cette question jusqu'au mois de septembre prochain.

Votre obéissant serviteur,

Agent des Indiens.

Le Secrétaire,
Département des Affaires des Indiens,
OTTAWA.
Sir,

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 27th, and in reply to inform you that after having examined the recreation halls in the basement of the Senior school, I believe that the project of using one for the teaching of drawing is practical. I spoke of it with the Reverend Father Superior who, although hesitating seems willing to make the sacrifice.

I have also spoken of that project to Mr. C. Mather, the teacher who suggested that the change should not be done before the month of September next for the reason that there is only four drawing classes to complete the present scholastic year. Consequently, the lady teachers of the Senior school informed me that these rooms were particularly useful to them at the end of the scholastic year.

Finally, at their meeting last night, I submitted the matter to the members of the Otagoawage Council who understand that that change can not easily be made before the opening of the next scholastic year. Consequently, I would advise to postpone this question until September next.

I am obediently yours,

[Signature]

The Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, relative to the fitting up of a room in the basement of the Senior School on the Caughnawaga Reserve in which to conduct the evening manual training classes.

In this connection I have to say that the Department will approve of the present arrangements being continued for the balance of the present school year. You should, however, arrange during the summer holidays to fit up one of the rooms in the basement. You should see that this room is locked off from the rest of the building and a separate entrance arranged. Please keep all expenses for the purpose as low as possible, and have this room ready by September 1st, next, when the classes resume after the holidays. When the arrangements are completed, you should forward an account, in triplicate, properly certified, covering any expenditure incurred.

MEMO FOR FILE:

With reference to the vocational training class on the Caughnawaga reserve, I discussed this with Agent Letourneau when I was on the reserve on September 2nd.

This class has been conducted for the past four years, but I found, after making enquiry, that very few adults have been attending it. The majority were boys who were not sufficiently advanced to profit by the instruction given.

The supplies for this class had recently been placed in the girls' playroom in the senior school. (This action was authorized by official letter of June 11th). This arrangement would not be satisfactory, as it would mean that there would be no playroom available for the girls.

The Department has been allowing the instructor the sum of $85 a month.

In view of the only room available for this class being the girls' playroom—which, as pointed out above, will seriously inconvenience the girls in the Senior School—the small number of adult Indians that have been taking advantage of the class and the lack of funds during the current year to meet the salary of the instructor, I recommend that the class be discontinued.

The supplies used by the class—a list of which was forwarded to the Department with Agent Letourneau's letter of July 2nd, last—can be stored in a small vacant room in the basement of the Kateri School.

Montreal, July 8, 1933.

Dear Sir,

I am forwarding you my final report for the scholastic year which has just closed.

Allow me to inform you that I am satisfied with the results obtained throughout the term. On an average, about 90% were present at the lessons, 75% of whom did excellent work and derived splendid benefits therefrom. The general deportment showed marked improvement, the attention was sustained far better than in the past, and the sense of rhythm more developed.

Among the girls, I endeavored to cultivate elegance and ease of movement.

A certain number of pupils following my instructions, were not able to keep up with the others owing to slowness in grasping explanations.

If you grant me the favor of renewing my contract for September next, I shall organize a special class for these subnormals and see what can be done with them.

Mr. Phelan, whom I had the honor of meeting at the Closing Exercises at Senior School, seemed pleased with our Physical Culture demonstration. In spite of the intense heat
that night, the pupils performed their exercises ably, except perhaps the minims from whom however, one does not expect as much perfection as with the more advanced classes.

I close with sincere thanks and with the hope that I may continue to give the Caughnawaga children, lessons in Physical Training this coming September.

Yours respectfully,

Mr. A.F. MacKensie, Secretary,
Ottawa.

Reverend Madam:

I am in receipt of a report from Miss Moodie in which she states that she recently discussed with you the advisability of giving instruction in weaving and other handicraft work at the Caughnawaga Roman Catholic School rather than in typewriting etc. Miss Moodie states that such action would meet with your approval.

Please let me have a definite statement from you in connection with Miss Moodie's suggestion. While I favour the teaching of the handicrafts mentioned in Miss Moodie's report, at the same time I do not want to create any ill feeling on the Reserve.

Do you feel that the majority of the children and their parents would favour this instruction rather than what is being given at the present time? Would it be possible to keep about 10 of the typewriters and use the rest of the room for handicrafts? In this way the commercial work could be taught to those especially desiring it and at the same time the handicraft instruction would be available.

I trust that you will give me the benefit of your experience on the Caughnawaga Reserve and let me know exactly how you feel in regard to the matter. An early reply would be appreciated.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

In reply to your letter of the 16th instant, I wish to say that I think Miss Moodie's suggestion might be more practical for our Caughnawaga pupils than Commercial Subjects.

Domestic arts are in demand in all our residential schools in Canada. No doubt but the majority of our girls would like the novelty. What reaction this change would have on the parents and the "Fathers of the Town" is hard to tell. They are generally so contrary.

At all events, it might be wise to keep up the Commercial Department, for a time at least. If we begin weaving in the early spring, it would probably start the parents thinking and talking on the matter and give us an inkling as to what should definitely be done at the opening of schools in September.

I also intend to start Manual Training with the boys about the 15th of March if you indorse the plan. One of the Jesuit Brothers, a skilled cabinet maker, would give the boys about six hours a week, until the middle of June. Kindly let me know what compensation the Department would allow for his services. He is residing here at the rectory.

With kind regards from all the staff at the R.C. Schools.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY:-

Re: Vocational Training, Caughnawaga R.C.
Indian Day School.

(a) Sewing:
We allowed an amount of $75.00 during the academic year 1937-38 for the purchase of sewing material. Four hundred (400) articles were made and, for your information, I enclose a detailed statement indicating the number made in each grade. There is no question that the pupils are receiving a splendid training in sewing, crochet work, knitting and embroidery. The dresses worn by the seven girls who had completed their course were made by themselves from some of the material supplied by the Department. They were extremely well done.

(b) Cooking:
There was an excellent display of preserves, etc., which had been made by the pupils, under the direction of one of the Sisters.

(c) Manual Training:
You will remember that, last March, we authorized the Sister to expend a small amount of money in order to commence manual training work for the boys, and I also authorized at that time the employment of Brother who is residing at the Priest's House on the reserve. This man - Brother Gauthier - is a practical carpenter and cabinet maker. He has had some previous experience with Indian children, having been attached to some Indian residential school in western Canada. The Principal reports that he handles the boys very well.

One large work table was purchased but the five smaller work tables used by the boys were made by them under the direction of Brother Gauthier. While this branch has only been in operation for a few months, it is reported to me that the boys are extremely interested. Some very creditable work has been done and several samples of their work were on display.

Brother Gauthier is extremely interested and has given a great deal of time. He is prepared to continue for the next academic year and Reverend Sister Cleophas suggests that we allow him $50.00 a month. From what I have seen, I consider this would be reasonable and I would recommend this allowance for your favourable consideration.

(d) Spinning and
(d) Spinning and Weaving:

You will remember that, last March, authority was given for the removal of some of the typewriters from the typewriting room. About the same time one 30" loom and four 45" looms were purchased from the Welfare Vote. My memory is that it was understood, as soon as the typewriters were removed, one or two looms at least would be placed in the space formerly occupied by them and this work commenced immediately, in order to ascertain if the pupils were more interested in it than in the commercial work.

I was much surprised to learn that, on the instructions of Miss Moodie, the five looms have been stored in the basement of the Kateri School and instructions were given by Miss Moodie that they were not to be used. I understand, also, that Miss Moodie has purchased a great deal of material which is stored in the basement of the Kateri School.

As Miss Moodie is away from the office today, I have not yet had an opportunity of discussing the matter with her, but I can see no reason why the looms were bought and placed in the basement of one of the schools, when there are at least two of the Reverend Sisters at present on the staff of the Caughnawaga R. C. School who, Rev. Sister Cleophas states, are able to teach weaving, etc.

Sister Cleophas has no objection to abandoning the commercial course and substituting the weaving, etc., as she considers that at the present time the latter would be much more practical.

I, therefore, recommend that this action be taken for the academic year 1938-39. I feel, however, that before any more typewriters are distributed, I should be consulted, as we have received several requests from residential schools for typewriters, which have been unable to supply. The typewriters now present in the Caughnawaga school were bought from the appropriation for Indian Education, and, if we are abandoning this work, the logical course to take is to distribute the typewriters to different schools. I think that six or seven typewriters should be left at Caughnawaga. Some of them will be required by the teachers to prepare their work, returns, etc., while it might be that a few of the pupils would like to learn typewriting and, in that event, the machines would be available. There is no doubt that any machines left at Caughnawaga will receive the very best of care.

In the event of our discontinuing the commercial class, Sister Cleophas states, as mentioned above, that there are two Sisters on the staff at the present time who are qualified to teach weaving, etc., and this will mean that there will be no increase in the paylist, as the salary now paid the commercial teacher can be transferred to one of the teachers who is in charge of the weaving, etc.

While the girls who have attended Ste. Martine or St. Jacques have done very good work and have received

a fair knowledge -
a fair knowledge of weaving, at the same time I would not consider that they are as yet sufficiently qualified to teach others with the hope of being very successful.

In the event of making a change in the course suggested in this memorandum, I recommend that the present commercial room be used for the sewing room. This will mean that the sewing room and domestic science room will be beside each other.

The looms should be installed in the room at present used for sewing. This is a large room and I consider is the most suitable in which to have the looms.

Reverend Madam:

I understand that "the Caughnawaga Weaving Studio" is doing excellent work, but that further materials are required. This authorizes you to purchase materials to the value of not more than $45.00 at present, it being understood that you will notify us before the supply is exhausted.

Miss Moodie has recommended that Miss Carol Brinson should be engaged to assist one day a week in connection with the weaving school, and this is approved. Will you please telephone Miss Brinson and arrange to have her come to Caughnawaga on whatever day you think best each week. I am writing Mr. Indian Agent Briebois with reference to submitting vouchers in this connection.

We are sending by express to Adirondack Junction one of the small Guildcraft looms, as requested. May I suggest that the boys might be able to make three or four stands similar to that with which the small loom is equipped. There is no patent on these stands and it is all right for them to be made in the manual training class.

As arranged with Miss Moodie, we will wire you as soon as definite information is received regarding the ordering of scarves by the R. C. M. Police. We feel that you are to be congratulated on having the school so well organized as to permit the acceptance of such an order.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Rossy,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Miss Moody,

I am sorry to have to bother you about this, but it seems to be the only way left. On March 1st, I mailed Mr. Bessette the statement for the months of Jan. & Feb. I waited until March, the 30th, and when the cheque didn't come in, I wrote to him again. I have not heard from him and I thought you might be able to find out what was the matter. I remain,

Ottawa,
April 13th, 1939.

Dear Miss Brinson:

I am sorry that there has been so much delay regarding your account, but on looking up our records I find that the voucher was submitted by Mr. Brisebois of March 10.

It has been passed for payment but is being held until the appropriation for the new fiscal year is available.

There are literally hundreds of accounts awaiting payment and I am afraid the cheque will not be issued for several weeks yet.

Mr. Smith has sent in several of the dish towels made of the warp you set up at Oka and they are really very nice.

With best wishes,

Yours very truly,

Welfare & Training Service.

Montreal, Que.
Ottawa, April 12, 1939.

Dear Mr. Raymond:

Mr. Pratt has suggested that I submit to you a summary of the vocational training programme promoted by this Branch at the Indian day schools on the Caughnawaga reserve.

The Sisters in charge of the Roman Catholic Day School on the Caughnawaga reserve have for a number of years provided a certain amount of vocational instruction for girls. This instruction consisted in the main of typewriting, shorthand and domestic science such as dressmaking, fruit preserving, etc. Despite this provision, however, the major portion of the study period was devoted to the regular academic studies, regardless of the ability of the pupils to pursue these studies with any hope of success. The course of study provided, therefore, at the Caughnawaga schools was carefully reviewed by the officials of this Branch about 18 months ago, with the result that provision now is made for a course of study in hand loom weaving for girls. Not only are the girls taught hand loom weaving, but they are taught how to make for sale gentlemen's ties and scarfs, scarfs for ladies, automobile rugs, towels, belts, and in fact everything in woven goods for which a demand may develop from time to time. In addition to the course provided at Caughnawaga, a number of the senior girls have been sent to L'Ecole Menagere Regionale at St. Martine and St. Jacques, Quebec, where they have pursued post graduate studies. It is our hope that when these girls return to the reserve they will be in a position to provide instruction in weaving to members of the adult population on the reserve.

An agreement has been reached also, whereby a

Maxime Raymond, Esq., M.P.,
House of Commons,
Ottawa, Ont.
Lay Brother of the Jesuit Order provides daily instruction in carpentry work, wood carving, metal work or in fact any particular course in which a group of the boys may be interested. You will be interested to learn that we have on display in the Branch here samples of the work accomplished at Caughnawaga. It is scarcely necessary to state that we would be delighted to have you inspect this work any time at your convenience.

Mr. Pratt intimated to me during the course of our conversation that a report had reached you regarding the construction of a vocational school in the province of Quebec by the Department. I can only state that the desirability of establishing a vocational school for Indians anywhere in Canada has never been considered by the Department. It is my personal opinion that vocational instruction amongst Indians has not yet advanced to the stage where the erection of a building is in any sense urgent or necessary. It is scarcely necessary to add that, should you desire additional information, I shall be glad to supply it at any time.

Yours very sincerely,

R. H. Hoey
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, Sept. 11, 1940.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

While organizing our Weaving Studio Work for 1940-1941, we realize more and more that an extra cupboard would be of great help.

We are asking your permission to have one constructed by the boys of the Manual Training Department under Brother Gauthier's direction. This cupboard would be similar to the one built last year, but with the exception that we would appreciate a glass-door top in which different woven articles could be displayed for the benefit of the numerous visitors to the school. As it is now, Sister M. George is obliged to take every article out of different drawers and then place everything back again.

Furthermore, we have decided to transfer the Sewing Room to one of the Weaving Rooms and vice versa in order to facilitate supervision and render the work less fatiguing. We believe in this way, we will obtain still better results.

Would you also approve a display case built on another cupboard which we are already using for the same reasons as above but to be used by the Domestic Science teacher?

We thank you for your attention to the above matters and we wish to assure you that we are asking for it, only because we believe it would be of great benefit for both the teacher and the pupils.

Respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. R.A. Hoey,
Ottawa.
Dear Mr. Phelan:

After conferring with Brother Gauthier regarding the amount of wood needed for the Manual Training Classes, we come to the conclusion that $100.00 to be spent in two instances would suffice for this year.

This amount would cover the cost of material needed to build supplementary school equipment which the brother is very willing to construct for us.

May we, therefore, be authorized to spend this amount? We thank you again for all your kindnesses and we beg to remain

Very respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Ottawa.

Ottawa, June 5, 1941.

Dear Sister Jean de Dieu:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 4th instant, in which you intimate that the weaving class is likely to remain open and in operation during the regular summer holiday period.

It is my understanding that it will be necessary to keep the looms at Caughnawaga in operation during this period to meet the orders now on hand or orders that are likely to reach the Department during the summer months. It is not expected that Sister M. Geary will forego her usual vacation to supervise this work. Arrangements have already been made whereby Miss Foisy will take charge of the work. Miss Foisy is one of our most dependable and most experienced teachers and has been for some years in charge of one of our schools at the St. Regis Reserve.

It is our intention, also, to make arrangements whereby the school property will be thoroughly protected.

The present arrangement whereby classes are conducted in the school is in many respects far from satisfactory. It is my hope that some day a building will be available in which this weaving class can be conducted. However, in view of the critical period in which we find ourselves it is not at all likely that the funds necessary for the construction of such a building will be available in the immediate future. In the meantime, conditions call for the exercise of a great deal of patience and forbearance on the part of all our teachers and officials. It is my hope that the spirit of cooperation will be very much in evidence, as I am sure it will be, at Caughnawaga during this period.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare and Training.

Rev. Sister Jean de Dieu,

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Mrs. Moodie has intimated that she would like to have the Commercial Reading Studio in progress during the summer months.

In fact three obstacles are facing us concerning this affair. First, Mr. George usually must have his holidays and for that purpose she will have for the Mother House about the end of the current month—then Mrs. Moodie understands her main arrangements to have the work carried on by lay women, responsible she says, to which she can assure...

This fact, Mr. Hoey, is my fear. We are dealing with Indians, and as much as we want to cooperate with the department in this regard, I doubt very much that there will be no great inconveniences to the depart...
ment of the girls if there is no strict supervision...and this is the main reason why the summer school does not entirely appeal to me. As far as the meaning is concerned, the appointed ladies will see to that but our Senior School has free access to the upper stories and I feel quite responsible for the good condition of the building. Our janitor, Mr. Peters, told me, in a very definite manner that he would strictly supervise the building during this working period, but not without being paid extra for it....In fact we'll find he is getting plenty for what he does here, itself. This is his attitude and I am sure these would be no damage done to the buildings while he is in charge...and all will be well.

Trusting that you will make some arrangements for the safety of the entire situation here,

I remain,

Very sincerely yours,

S.M. Jean de Dieu, s.o.
Principal.

Mr. Doucet:

I am returning your copies of the Manuals of Woodwork, "Evans" and "Justison", and thank you for their use. I delayed in sending these books, because they are very practical and useful to the boys, and as we have but two other copies of each, we have been using yours.

Some three weeks ago, we received an order of books containing two books by Evans, two by Justison, two by Hamilton and two "Problems in Farm Woodwork". As the Job Sheets refer the pupils to reading matter in "Evans" and "Justison" especially, any additional copies of these texts will be appreciated.

We are grateful for the interest which you take in our boys, who, in general, are profiting by their new course. Mr. Wescott finds that the majority are doing well.

Mr. A. J. Doucet,
welfare and Training Division,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

You have already received the regular reports from the Reverend Sister Principal concerning the woodworking class of the Caughnawaga R.C. Indian Day Schools. In addition, I have thought that you would appreciate a brief summary of the general results obtained and the progress made in the workshop.

As you know, the class commenced operation on October 9th. Twelve boys were enrolled in the class at the beginning. Three others were admitted during the year. Only eight boys remained at the end of the year, the seven others having left school for various reasons: age, moving from the Reserve, general misconduct etc.

During the first part of the year, from October to the Christmas recess, all the boys were engaged on the same project at the same time. The work outlined in the first nine projects was performed by all the pupils during this time. All the boys acquired very satisfactory skill in crosscutting, ripping, squaring up stock etc.

The Christmas holidays and the fire caused a long interruption of the woodworking course. The woodworking classes were resumed in the latter half of January.

As soon as they returned to the shop, three or four of the older boys took the attitude that it would be of little use for them to do woodworking, as they would be leaving school in February or March, as soon as they would be sixteen years old.

This attitude of a few boys could not be anything but an obstacle to the general progress of the class. The indifference and the bad example of these boys could naturally not have any good effect on the others.

After your visit, when you insisted on the continued attendance of these pupils and gave permission for me to divide the pupils into two groups, much better progress was made.
During the latter part of the year, after the boys had acquired the elementary skills of which I have spoken, more freedom was given in the choice of projects. The pupils were permitted to choose a project and submit it to the instructor. This stimulated interest. Acting upon your instructions, I allowed the pupils to take home the articles which they had made. This also proved to be a great stimulus. Many useful objects were made: tool-chests, plant-stands, fernieres, hat-racks, tables, milk-stools, etc.

I feel very well satisfied with the work of the eight boys who remained until the end of the school year, while I regret that some of the older boys, who had been anxiously awaiting their birthdays to be released from compulsory school attendance, did less work than I should have liked; I feel that even they have acquired much knowledge and skill which should be of service to them. Some of the others who left during the school year had made very satisfactory progress. In general, I believe that those who did not progress were those who did poor work in their other classes. One or two boys who did rather poorly in their other classes, through lack of talent rather than of good will, did satisfactory shopwork.

Pupils who completed the year's work:

Ernest Montour - Very good
Robert Jacobs - Do
Ernest Lafleur - Capable, but unstable - Likes to avoid hard work-
Gordon Curotte - Good worker -
Richard White - Less talented than some - willing - interested -
shows initiative and imagination -
Herbert Nice - Very good -
John Latour - These two boys admitted after Christmas did Alex. Jacco very satisfactory work.

Pupils who left during year:

Harry Paul - very good worker - left on account of age -
Carl Bell - Excellent - Moved away from Reserve. -
The others, Jos. Diabo, Osler Bush, Dave Norton, Geo. Mayo,
Peter Jacobs, varied in skill and good will.

I trust that this brief report will be useful.
I enclose inventory of tools and material.

With best personal regards,

Yours respectfully,

E. E. Wescott,
Instructor.

February 8, 1943.

Memorandum:

MR. HOEY

As directed by you, I visited the Caughnawaga Reserve on Friday, February 5. I first discussed with the Indian Agent the case of Mr. Albany Robert, the present caretaker of the school. I advised Mr. Brisebois that Robert's extension would expire on July 1, 1943. Mr. Brisebois mentioned that there was an Indian named Bush, 41 years of age, who he thought would make a suitable caretaker and Mr. Brisebois will discuss the matter with him again with a view to ascertaining definitely if he is prepared to accept the position. Mr. Brisebois agreed that one capable man should be able to handle the work that is required at the present time.

I also discussed with the Sister Superior her recent letters regarding Robert. It appears that the latter is extremely cranky and apparently will only do what suits himself. He is not sweeping the schools regularly and evidently considers himself the owner of the buildings.

Previous to the destruction by fire of the Senior School Robert was living in the basement of that building and at the time of the fire he told the then Sister Superior that it was impossible for him to secure a room and she allowed him to live temporarily in a room in the basement of the teachers' residence. He is still living there and expects the Sisters to supply him with his food, which they have been doing for over a year. Besides, he keeps several dogs in the barn on our property. These animals cause the Sisters considerable trouble and, in addition, Robert expects them to provide food for these dogs. Another matter that was brought out was that there are two cars stored for the winter in the barn, one belonging to the Medical Officer and the other to an Indian and Robert is collecting monthly rental reported to be approximately $2.50 for storing these cars although, as you realize, the building belongs to the Department and not to Robert.

With your approval it is my intention to write to Indian Agent Brisebois and instruct him to advise Robert that he will have to find another boarding house before February 20, as I do not see any reason why he should be allowed to live in the basement of the teachers' residence or why the Sisters should provide him with food as Robert is being paid a reasonable salary and he should provide his own maintenance. I also suggest that Robert be definitely instructed by the Agent to give more attention to his duties for the balance of the current academic year. Needless to add, instructions to the Agent should include directions to Robert to remove his dogs from the barn.
I also ascertained that the Agent was successful in securing oil and consequently the furnace in the teachers' residence has not been converted to the use of coal. As a matter of fact it was impossible to do this as they have not yet been able to secure the necessary parts, although they have been on order for some months.

I visited all classrooms with the Sister Superior and found a good attendance and both teachers and pupils appeared very happy. Mr. Wescott has a class of 20 boys for manual training and he was very enthusiastic regarding the progress they are making this year which he claims is much improved over last year.

The Sister Superior suggested that the manual training room be transferred from the Kateri School to the Eastern School. All the boys are in the latter school and, as the basement in this school is in good condition, I can see no reason why the transfer should not be made at all, of course, involve some expense for extra wiring etc., the present manual training room in the basement of the Kateri School can be used for giving sewing and cooking lessons to the girls who are in this building. I have spoken to Mr. Doucet about the proposed change and he can see no objection to it. With your approval it is my intention to write to the Indian Agent giving him the necessary authority to expend whatever is necessary to make the change.

I also visited the Caughnawaga U.C. School and had a half hour's conference with both teachers. Their attendance has been good and the teachers claimed that the children were making very satisfactory progress. Mr. Wescott visits them at regular intervals and assists the teachers in giving some manual training instruction to the boys.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa,
February 8, 1943.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

When Mr. Phelan was in Caughnawaga on Friday the Sister Superior discussed with him the possibility of transferring the manual training room from the Kateri School to the Eastern School. The room vacated in the Kateri School would then be used for a combined sewing and domestic science room. We have considered this proposal carefully and we feel that it would be in the best interests of all parties concerned to make this arrangement. It will involve some small amount of extra wiring in the basement of the Eastern School and it will also be necessary to cover the ceiling with Ten-test, or some similar material, in order to deaden the noise. Mr. Doucet will visit the reserve this week and will discuss this matter further with you and I should appreciate it if you would arrange to have the necessary change made at the earliest possible date. When it is completed, you should forward a list of the equipment required for the sewing and domestic science room. Only the very necessary articles should be requested.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Herewith enclosed, you will find triplicate copy of permit from the Department of Munitions and Supply which I have duly filled out and which we would ask you to sign. May we ask you also to issue an official order from the Department covering the following articles, without which we cannot purchase anything from the Canadian General Electric Company:

1 RA 392 Range
1 TL2 Toaster
1 F52 Iron
1-135D25 Hotplate
5-135D20

There is practically no choice in the stoves, the Government allowing the sale of only two models. We have chosen the 4-plate range with one oven which retails at $176 but we understand that this stove will carry something like a 35% discount since it is bought directly. This direct purchase is allowed because it is a Government Purchase.

The four hotplates mentioned above are the only four left in stock. Therefore, may we ask you to send the official order to us here in Caughnawaga and we will take it directly to the General Electric to complete the business with them?

We spent hours at Caverhill Learmont trying to obtain kitchen utensils but at the end of that time, we found we were still short of seventy eight articles. Caverhill-Learmont personnel were very kind to us and they referred us directly to a manufacturer: The General Steel Wares. We were more fortunate there. We tried to be very reasonable and bought serviceable articles at the best price to be found.

We have a few more items to get. We are so happy to think that we will have a Domestic Science Department once again.
We thank you and all the other members of the Department who helped to make this reorganization a reality. It seems that we will miss Senior School less with that Department functioning once again.

Mr. Wescott is giving all his time and his experience to make this project a success. The lumber is to arrive tomorrow and the work will begin immediately.

Awaiting your early reply, we beg to remain

Yours very respectfully,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

[Signature]

Principal.

Mr. R. A. Hoey, Esq.,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
March 24, 1943.

Caughnawaga, April 15, 1943.

Dear Mr. Doucet:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter requesting the basic units for Weaving. I have them worked out quite thoroughly but I am not quite satisfied with them yet. So many unusual things have happened of late, that I have been unable to give the units the attention they require. However, I promise them within a few days.

May I profit of this letter to ask you to authorize the additional purchase of approximately $30.00 worth of lumber for the boys of the Woodwork. They are running short of material for their projects.

Furthermore, since the Woodwork has been transferred to the Eastern School, we have noticed that the floor of the cellar is constantly wet. At Mr. Wescott's suggestion, I would ask if it would be possible to build with the boys' help, a rough spruce floor. Mr. Wescott says that the workshop measures 19 ft X 50 ft. and a 2-inch plank would fill the bill.

Thanking you for your kind attention to these matters, I beg to remain

Very respectfully yours,

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, Aug. 21, 1943.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Herewith enclosed, please find all forms duly filled by four new members of the Caughnawaga Teaching Staff. We hope they will prove satisfactory.

May we ask if $100.00 is again authorized for the Domestic Science Department and $85.00 for the Sewing Class? We are expecting a very nice group of girls and boys this year and we believe that you will have every reason to be proud of your Caughnawaga Indians at Commencement Exercises next June. We are hoping that many of those who left us during the scholastic year 1942-1943 will return. Will we have a truant officer this year?

Our General Prefect of Studies has offered us many valuable books which could be used by the teachers as reference books as so many of our personal books were destroyed in the Senior School fire. May we be authorized to purchase two sectional bookcases, one for each of the two village schools for these books? We thought we could find some serviceable bookcase in some second-hand shop in Montreal.

We are also enclosing a picture of our boys taken last June. They are happily displaying their woodwork. Thought it would interest you and Mr. Hoey as well as Mr. Doucet.

Respectfully yours,

SISTERS OF SAINT ANN

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL PURCHASING AGENT

I desire to refer to my memorandum of the 25th ultimo, enclosing an account which included the cost of 2 bookcases for the domestic science class at the Caughnawaga R.C. School.

The domestic science teacher supplies cooking recipes and each pupil enters these in a book and, while the recipes are used during the year, it is intended that they should be kept for use after the pupil graduates. These books are kept in the domestic science room until the close of the term. It is necessary to have a proper case for storing these. There are also other articles, such as dishes, used for showing the proper way to set tables. These also have to be stored in a convenient place. From personal knowledge of the work that is being done in the domestic science class at this school, I feel that these two cases are necessary.

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, August 5, 1944.

Dear Mr. Doucet:

Herewith enclosed, please find woodwork report duly signed by Mr. Wescott.

Mr. Wescott was here a few days ago, inquiring whether or not he was being employed again for the school year 1944-1945. Will you kindly advise us if there is to be any change? He seemed to be somewhat worried over the matter.

Also, if Mr. Wescott is continuing his duties with us, will you kindly authorize him to place his order for the necessary lumber now? We were some three months without material last year and we would like to avoid such an occurrence again. Thank you.

Respectfully yours,

Sisters of Saint Ann

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. A. Doucet,
Ottawa.

[Handwritten note:]
I would appreciate receiving some shop sheet plans.
Ottawa, August 8, 1944.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Quebec.

Enclosed please find a copy of a letter which I received from Sister Mary George dated August 5, 1944. The Department is pleased to employ Mr. Wescott to teach Manual Training to the boys for the year 1944-45. You may inform him that no change had been anticipated.

As regards the second paragraph you may purchase the lumber necessary for the year 1944-45.

It is difficult for us to understand the statement contained in the last two lines of the inclosed letter. We would appreciate your comments on this matter.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division
Philip Phelan, Esq., Chief, Training Div., Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 8th instant enclosing copy of a communication from the Sister Superior dealing with the manual training for the coming school year.

Mr. Westcott has been informed that his services will be required in the Fall.

Relative to the statement contained in the last two lines of the Sister's letter I may say that last Spring difficulties were experienced in getting the kind of lumber that Mr. Westcott wanted. Instead of receiving the lumber ordered in a single load the lumber merchant had to deliver same little by little as he could not get the lumber himself. However I am not ready to say that they were without lumber for three months as they used, in the meantime, lumber that was stored at the residence of the Sisters. The delay in obtaining the lumber is regretted but it was unavoidable due to the present conditions.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.
Ottawa, August 12, 1944.

Mr. F. Brisebois, Indian Agent, Caughnawaga, Que.

With reference to your letter of the 10th instant, please let me know what quantity of lumber will be required for manual training purposes at the Caughnawaga School during the coming academic year. If you consider you can secure this lumber locally, you might let me know the price and the name and address of the firm from whom you could secure it.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Caughnawaga, Que.,
August 24, 1944.

Philip Phelan, Esq., Chief, Training Division, Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

I have your letter of the 12th instant dealing with the lumber required for manual training purposes at Caughnawaga for the coming academic year and in this connection to inform that Mr. Wescott, teacher of that class, was interviewed and stated that 300 ft. of clear pine or basswood (preferably basswood) and 200 ft. of birch or ash (preferably ash) would be required.

J.P. Dupuis Ltd., Lumber Merchants, Lachine, Que., could supply the above at the following prices:

- Clear pine or basswood, kiln dried, no. 1 quality $180.00 per 1000 feet. B.M.
- Quality as above for ash wood. $200.00 per 1000. B.M.

Kindly advise if this material will be ordered from the above firm or purchased through the Branch.

(Frs. Brisebois)

Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, August 21, 1944.

Dear Mr. Doucet:

Following our conversation of early July regarding the allowances made for Domestic Science Department and the purchase of material for the sewing and knitting classes, will you kindly notify us if the Department has approved the expenditure of $155? As you will readily remember, the usual allowance was $85 but as the cost of these materials has increased considerably and as some seventy extra girls are to benefit of sewing and knitting classes this year, the extra $50 would be very much appreciated.

Also, can you tell us whether or not there will be discarded socks to be ripped this year? We have enough wool to be twisted for about two months only.

We would also appreciate if you could forward discarded service men's clothing—the girls could get started on that in early September and make up their school uniform. As we stated before, the navy blue or the air force color is preferred.

Trusting that you will be able to give us an early reply on these matters, we remain

Respectfully yours,

Sisters of Saint Ann

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. A. Doucet,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, August 31, 1944.

Dear Sister George:

With reference to your letter of the 21st instant, the Department will allow an amount of $185.00 for the purchase of materials for the domestic science class at the Caughnawaga R.C. School for the coming academic year. I presume the purchases will be made in small amounts and accounts will be sent in from time to time during the year.

I am going to Nova Scotia next week and on my return I hope to spend part of the day at Caughnawaga. At that time I will discuss with you your request for discarded military clothing.

Yours very truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Reverend Sister Mary George,
Principal,
R.C. Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga, Que.
Teachers' Residence,
Caughnawaga, August 30, 1944.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

While cleaning up the Kateri School cellar, we found a box of things salvaged from the fire at the Agent's office and imagine our surprise to see that it contained some eight bundles of 2/32 yarn which undoubtedly had been purchased for the weaving studio.

The Domestic Science teacher and myself wondered if you would authorize us to use this yarn for the pupils' projects this year. It is much too fine but with our spinning wheel, we will teach the girls to triple it while twisting and then to use it for their socks or mittens, etc. Wouldn't it be grand if we could find our Senior School in the ruins? Even nuns have wild dreams occasionally.

Trusting to receive a favorable answer to this letter, we beg to remain

Yours respectfully,

Sisters of Saint Ann

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. R. A. Hoey, Esq.
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
September 1, 1944.

Dear Sister George:

With reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo, I cannot see any reason why you should not use the yarn to which you refer.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Sister M. George,
Principal,
R.C. Indian Day School,
Caughnawaga, Que.

Philip Phelan,

This will acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st instant in which you inform that a Manual Training teacher for Caughnawaga may be located.

This place belongs to one Arthur Beauvais, who has appointed his brother Louis Edward Beauvais, to look after its rental, but as running water, toilets facilities etc., are wanted the latter has to communicate with the owner in order to inquire if he would be willing to include same in his dwelling and, if so, what rental he would expect.

Arthur Beauvais who is living at Ste-Marguerite, Lake Masson, could not be reached as he was away in the bush, guiding a party of hunters. He is expected very shortly when we will manage to get in touch with him and communicate with you immediately.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Neary,

Mr. Doucet has left with me the attached letter from Mr. Brisebois of the Caughnawage Indian Reserve, Quebec, and has requested me to prepare a draft lease of Mr. Arthur Beauvais' location in this reserve for the use of the manual training teacher as a residence.

As you are aware, Section 50 grants authority to the Minister to lease, on behalf of an Indian upon his application, his location. The attached draft lease, with this in mind, is between the Minister as lessor and His Majesty the King as lessee. I have attempted to set down the conditions of the alterations and lease in this draft document. It is possible that they may need modification or change in some way.

The form of lease is satisfactory and if you are satisfied that all the conditions are included it may be submitted to the Deputy's Office for execution.

[Signature]

Departmental Solicitor.
Att., Mr. Doucet.

Caughnawaga, Que.,
October 31, 1947.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I wish to refer to your letter of the 21st instant
and to our reply of the 28th, dealing with the renting of a
house at Caughnawaga for a Manual Training teacher and to
say that we have today received the visit of Mr. Arthur Beau-
vais of this Reserve presently living at the Domaine d'Este-
rel, Ste. Marguerite, Lake Masson, who is the owner of the
house referred to in my recent communication, and to say that
the above named is willing to rent his house under the follow-
ing conditions.

The owner would put in an electric water pump,
sinks, bathroom and inside toilets. He would finish the inside
with Ten Test or the equivalent. He would rewire his entire
building and would provide an electric water tank, Double
windows and doors. Also a 60 ampere electric panel for a
stove.

Beauvais would expect at least a two years lease
at an annual rental of $600.00 per year and would request one
year paid in advance in order to proceed with the above work
immediately. An early reply is requested by the locatee so
that he can come and supervise the repairs before the ski season
opens as he and his son and daughters are conducting a ski
schools in the Laurentians, and will be quite busy from the
last part of November.

It might be advisable that an official of the
Training Division visits the Reserve in that connection and
also with regards with other matters pertaining to Schools
on the Reserve.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, December 16, 1947.

Dear Mr. Westcott:

The Department has recently engaged a manual training teacher to take charge of the work at the Caughnawaga School effective January 1st, 1947. Under these circumstances your services will not be required after the end of the current month.

The Department appreciates very much the assistance you have given us during the past few years. We realize that you did this in large part as a patriotic effort and our officers from time to time have reported that the results you obtained have been quite satisfactory. Arrangements will be made to pay you salary for the month of January, 1948. The amount that has been deducted from your salary and placed in the Retirement Fund will also be returned to you with interest after the end of January.

I take this opportunity of expressing our appreciation for your work and to extend to you best wishes for the new year.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, January 28, 1948.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your communication of the 26th instant, I am pleased to note that you are completely installed in your new home. I hope that you will find it cozy and comfortable.

As regards the last paragraph of your letter in which you state that you are ready to be initiated in your new duties, I wish to say that it would probably be more advantageous for you to start in and feel your way along in order to find out the difficulties that you will encounter. Then after a couple of weeks of operation, I would drop in and give you the time that you require. However, if you feel that you would prefer that I go right at the beginning let me know and I will arrange to go sooner.

Yours truly,

A.J. Doucet,
Supervisor, Training Division.

Mr. R. Viau,
Manual Training Instructor,
Caughnawaga R.C. Day School,
Caughnawaga, Quebec.

AJD/HM.
Janvier, le 26, 1948
Caughnawaga, Qué.

Lachine, Qué.

Bien cher M. Léonard,

Après maintes difficultés, nous sommes enfin parvenus à entrer dans notre logis à Caughnawaga.

M. Brichebois a été bien disposé à mon égard sous les circonstances. Aussi Messieurs Eddy et Arthur Beaureais nous ont rendu des services très appréciables.

Je serais donc à votre disposition lorsqu'il vous conviendra de venir m'initier dans mes nouvelles fonctions.

Je demeure votre très oblige,

Royal Vian, Chef.

As you are aware, the Department agreed to allow an amount not exceeding $1,800. for improvements to the house owned by Mr. Arthur Beauvais and now used as a residence for the manual training instructor. Gentlemen:

You have no doubt been informed through our agent of the theft which took place in our Domestic Science Room in the beginning of February. The electric iron and the toaster were taken. The R.C.M.P. force took the matter in hand but the objects have not been found.

Our Domestic Science teacher, Sr. M. Alma, is in great need of these objects for her lessons. Would the Department kindly make this purchase or allow us to get them at the General Northern Electric in Montreal?

Yours sincerely,

[Signature]

Principal
Caughnawage, Que.,
March 1, 1948.

ENCL.

The Indian Affairs Branch, Dept., of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

You will find herewith the original of a letter from the Rev. Principal of the local R.C. Schools which is self-explanatory.

May I say that the Kateri School was broken in about one month ago and that the two articles mentioned were stolen. The R.C.M.P. officers have so far been unable to locate these electrical apparatus.

Will you please advise if it will be in order for the Sisters to make this purchase.

(Frs. Brisebois)
Superintendent,
Indian Agency.
March 8, 1948.

Mr. Frs. Brisebois,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency
Caughnawaga, P.Q.

DEPARTMENT OF MINES & RESOURCES
INDIAN AFFAIRS BRANCH - TRAINING DIVISION
OTTAWA

Attention: Mr. A. J. Doucet

Gentlemen:

The monthly report blanks for the Manual Training are being forwarded and I trust that they will meet with your approval. However, they need a little explanation since they do not correspond to your printed chart of basic operations.

Sister Mary Alma informs me that when these records were to be printed, you had asked her to prepare a complete program. Her multiple duties at that time allowed her to submit only the First Year program, which you accepted without the least change. But the lack of equipment and the local needs have forced her to revise the basic operations for the second and third years of knitting and for the three years of cooking, housekeeping, and sewing.

The last two will be submitted only in January as the Doctor has ordered Sister to take a complete rest for at least six weeks. (Mr. Neary sanctioned her leave of absence when he visited us on November 24.) Though this revision has not been approved by you, Sister has taken the liberty of preparing her monthly report according to her schedule, presuming that you would accept it "tel que". The report for the preparatory classes - Grades IV, V, VI - was made on the same basis as that of the previous months.

Would you please send us more Record Sheets for the four basic operations of Domestic Science and for the Woodwork. I believe that Mr. Viau made the request when you came in November. Sister Mary Alma also solicits the permission to use her December allowance to purchase necessary utensils for her Culinary Department.

Our new school is progressing rapidly since you sent Mr. Bock and Mr. Neary for inspection--such visits are real "pep-builders". May they be renewed often....

Very truly yours,

[Signature]

Montreal Technical School

Laying-Out and the Use of the Steel Square

Elementary geometry applied to carpentry and construction. — Brace measure using the square and mathematics. Geometrical drawing; polygons; ellipses and various curves, etc. — Arches of all kinds. — Use of the Stanley and Sargent steel squares in laying out arches. — Study and development of the scotia; vault arches and roots with 4, 5, 6 and 8 sides. — Pitch board tables for roofs. Study of tables suitable for common rafters for 13 regular pitches. — Table used for hips and valleys — steel rule application. — Table of hundredths and its application in calculating elevations. — Table for jack rafters and side cuts. — Shaping hip rafters; tracing the side cuts for jack rafters with irregular pitches; tracing out canopies of various designs; steeples of various designs; curved hip rafters; various types of domes; alcoves and vaults of varying styles; laying out door assemblies, wainscoting, English and French windows, rectangular and arched; preparation of templates; bills of material. — Approximate cost of material needed: $3.50, optional: 38 blue-prints at 16 cents each.

Forty Lessons

Guy Larin

Mr. Scott,

Recent reports received from the School Inspector and Agent show that the three schools on the St. Regis Reserve which are in charge of white teachers are doing excellent work and the pupils are making marked progress in their studies. There are five schools on this reserve, two of them being in charge of Indian teachers, and the results obtained at these two schools are in marked contrast to the other three. The Indian teachers have no qualifications or training and, while they are doing their best, they are handicapped by their lack of education. Both these teachers have been in the service of the Department for some years, Mrs. Back, who is in charge of the Chenail School, was appointed six years ago, and Miss Roundpint, now Mrs. Armstrong, who has the Cornwall Island School, has been there seven years.

I think it would be well to make a change after the summer holidays, as there would be no difficulty in getting duly qualified teachers to take charge of both these schools.

MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

On Saturday, the 29th ultimo, I visited the St. Regis reserve, for the purpose of meeting the teachers and trying to straighten out several little difficulties in connection with the professional services. I explained to them that any teacher who could not work and live in harmony with the others on the reserve had a disturbing influence which would interfere with success in the classrooms. Miss E. Frudhomme, of Chetlain, handed in her resignation to take effect as soon as she could be relieved. I definitely placed Miss Macduffy in charge of the girls, both as far as their classroom activity was concerned and in their residence. I laid down the rule that the village residence was to be used by the Chetlain and Chenail teachers from Saturday until Sunday only and that they upon those occasions were to meet a fair share of the cost and to assist in the work. I arranged for the installation of Miss Carmel Dunnigan, the new teacher at St. Regis Island, who is to live with the two village teachers in the village residence. Mr. MacGibbon, the new Indian agent, is quite sincere and eager to do his best and I believe in time will be a good representative.

Sir:

A report in respect to schools on the St. Regis Reserve.

Cornwall Island School.
Cornwall Island School did not open until January, 7th. 1929 due to illness of Mr. Chisholm, teacher, following an operation on tonsils. The Grippe has taken its course on the island, and a number of children have been absent from school due to sickness.

St. Regis Island School.
St. Regis Island school opened on January, 3rd. 1929. two pupils present. The Grippe being the cause of small attendance. Conditions have improved lately.

Chetlain School.
Chetlain school opened on January, 3rd. 1929. small attendance, due to sickness. School closed three days during week beginning Jan. 7th. Miss. Lagarde ill with the Grippe. In this section the Grippe appears to be the worst. A number of children have not returned to school since the holidays.

Chenail School.
Chenail school opened Jan. 3rd. 1929. Fair attendance. A number of pupils ill with the Grippe.

Village School.
The village school opened Jan. 3rd. 1929. Good attendance. A few of the village pupils are laid up with the Grippe.

August 8th, 1935

MEMORANDUM FOR MR. WILLIAMS

RE: ST. REGIS SCHOOL

The applicant, Frances Ursula Billings, is twenty-six years of age.

She attended Normal for one year and three years later, under the system then in Vogue in Ontario, returned to Normal for a further year's course. She holds a permanent second class certificate, together with an Elementary Agriculture certificate, Grade B Physical Training certificate, and Parts One of Elementary Art and Household Science.

She has taught for six years, all of this time in rural schools, where she taught the ordinary classes, and in addition for two years has been teaching in a rural school a class corresponding to the First Form of Collegiate as well as the other classes to be found in the ordinary rural school. From enquiries, she is highly regarded at her present school, where she is free to return next year, the present application not being made on account of any dismissal.
During her six years' teaching experience, she has been located in a district comprised largely of Polish people, where special attention has of necessity been paid to the teaching of the English language and where she has also had considerable experience in developing a course of teaching suitable for the development into useful Canadian citizens of children whose environment and home training has not in every case been conducive to such a development.

Mrs. Belling is a Roman Catholic.
St. Patrick's Rectory,
Ottawa, Ontario,

February 2nd, 1937.

Sir:

I have to advise that on account of an influenza epidemic now current on the Reserve, it has, with the recommendation of Br. Gardiner, been considered advisable to close the schools of the Agency.

During the last half of January there has been an increasing number of influenza cases, with some of pneumonia, both the Teachers and the school children being effected, the attendance at the schools dropping to a low percentage. Today's attendance at the Chemail school was 2 out of 22 enrolled, the other schools in proportion.

The schools will be closed for the remainder of the week, further action subject to the progress of the flu.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa,
Canada.
The matter of the schools of the reserve going on Daylight Saving or staying on Standard time was discussed.

Moved by Peter J. Day sec. by Angus Oake that the schools adhere to Standard time.

Carried.

There was considerable of a discussion developed regarding the time on which the schools should operate. A number of the residents of Cornwall Island find employment in Cornwall, which operated on advanced time. It did not seem to make much difference to the parents but it was considered it was best for the younger children if the schools operated on slow time.

D. P. McNaughton,
Agent.
St Regis, Que., October 5th, 1937.

September Report.

The schools of the reserve have opened for the fall term. The pupils were slow in returning to school, it being necessary to make several calls on parents in regard to their children's absence from school. The attendance has now reached approximately normal proportions. Manual training and domestic science classes have been started at the St Regis village Indian day school. Manual training has been taught during the last term in the Cornwall Island East, Indian day school.

D. P. McNaughton,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

As instructed via telegram, I got in touch with Miss Laura Leahy, Huntington Quebec, to secure her services as temporary teacher. Miss Leahy advised me that she could not consider a temporary position, but would be available for a position as a permanent teacher.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Yesterday afternoon I found a car load of people waiting in the pouring rain for the Indian Agent, who was down Chenaill. They wanted immediate attention as the Member of Parliament had sent them up to see about "a vacancy for a teacher from Huntingdon".

I told them one teacher had been ill, that the diagnosis at the beginning of the week had been diphtheria and a call sent to Ottawa for a relief teacher, but that Friday's laboratory report on the swab sent in had been negative, and that the teacher would be ready for work again in a few days.

The teacher who had received the message from Mr. Black is a smartly dressed, white-haired lady, who said she would not for a minute consider any school to which she would have to go in a boat, to say nothing of the additional tramp of a mile through the mud. She also said she would not consider a short assignment of a week or two. When I left the reserve about 4:30 they were still waiting for the Agent, and planning to telephone the member when they returned to Huntingdon.

Miss Billings had had rather a hard time. Dr. Gardiner, the reserve doctor, first landed her throat for quinsy, and then thought she had diphtheria and gave her a big shot of antitoxine. I think the cure has been worse than the disease, and she is anxious to see her own Doctor. I think she will have to go home for a few days to recuperate, and if so will see you in Ottawa this week. She is quite sure she will be ready for work a week from now. I think Mr. McNaughton will be anxious to know whether the school will be open at all this week or not, and by the time he could get mail now there will be only two days left in the week, so if you want to get him, phoning is about all that's left. The number is 35 F 21 (St. Regis, Que., through Fort Covington, N.Y.)

It has rained steadily ever since I left home, and I'm mud to the neck. I expect two of the shops will be sort of "leak open" tomorrow, but it's hard to get the men to pound logs in the rain.

Sincerely,

[Signature]

P.S. Wotta typewriter!
St. Regis Quebec,
October 25th, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to the illness of Miss Ursula Billings, reservation teacher, the clinical symptoms resembling diphtheria.

Departmental instructions, via telegram, was followed. Provincial Health Officer visited St. Regis and met Dr. Gardiner. The teachers of the Village and St. Regis island schools, following antidote treatment, was allowed to resume teaching.

Dr. Gardiner forwarded swabs for laboratory tests. Laboratory report received shows absence of diphtheria bacilli.

The Doctor has recommended a weeks convalescence for Miss Billings. It is expected that she will be able to return to her duties on the 2nd of November.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.
Dear Sir:

As instructed, via telephone, I got in touch with Mrs Henry Daust of Huntington Quebec, giving necessary information regarding temporary position as teacher during convalescence of Miss Billings. Mrs Daust accepted the position for such time as her services would be required and arrived in St. Regis this evening.

I will accompany Mrs Daust to the Chenail school and assist her in getting started.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

At this time I wish to refer you to your letter of June 1st, 1939 under File 33-1-1 and relative correspondence pertaining to the present Chenail Indian Day School.

As you are aware the matter of keeping the above school in fit condition to accommodate pupils has been quite a problem for some time past. At the present time, if this school is to continue in operation, the foundation must of necessity be replaced and the roof shingled. It is doubtful if the building in itself would warrant such an expenditure.

With respect to enlarging the capacity of the present Village School to take care of the children from the Chenail district, instead of building a school at the latter place, this would appear to be a step in the right direction as it is doubtful if any of the children attending would have more than a mile to walk. Of course transportation would have to be afforded during the navigable season so that there would be no danger of any pupils losing their lives while crossing the St. Regis River.

We would appreciate being advised if this matter has been given any further consideration by the Department.

It will be noted in some cases very low average for December. This is due to the flu epidemic mostly. In general it can be said that attendance at the various schools has maintained a high level. Such a high percentage is particularly noteworthy at the Chetlain school where it was difficult to get the boys to school. The reverse is now the case as far as the boys are concerned, with the exception of the Cornwall Ild. E. School no unusual difficulty is caused. The Village boys get the benefit of some training along this line when such is possible with the time at the disposal of the local constable, with only one man now stationed here less time can be devoted to such work amongst the boys. Due to the poor freezing of the St. Lawrence this winter it has not been possible during December to get to St. Regis Island school. The conditions are such that it is not safe to walk nor can a boat be used. Only emergency trips are made by the Indian residents of the island.

In general the children on the whole appear to be well-behaved and industrious. There is very little incentive for those children in our Quebec schools to devote much energy to studies after they reach the age of 15 as the prospect of being able to attend a high school is no better than in past years. The period of maximum attendance at school is between the ages of 15 and 16. The boys in particular just wont exert themselves too much after 15. This situation is most unfortunate as they have just reached a point in life when they should be capable of absorbing some knowledge. I feel though that if we could give them the kind of training they would like at this period we would be well repaid and would not have any attendance problem on our hands to contend with.

STAFF CONFERENCES

During 1945 such conferences were held monthly, weather permitting. At that time, due to absence of Agency Office Staff, all teachers were invited to sit in and discuss ways of improving general conditions amongst the Indian population of the reserve and, in particular, to find ways of becoming more proficient in our respective positions. Opposition was expected and received. Some teachers had been so long in one place it was hard for them to realize there was any relation between the individual school and the remainder of the community. After the barriers were torn down, much good came of these discussions.

On account of the heavy field programme to date for the current year, only the immediate office staff has been brought into consultation. It is hoped that, with the approval of senior officials concerned, it might be possible to have the teachers take part in these discussions again in the near future.
